datasetPresenter.name: nalbNRRLY1402_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence for Naganishia albida NRRL Y-1402
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence for Naganishia albida NRRL Y-1402
Cryptococcus albidus is an oleaginous yeast with capability to convert and store diverse organic carbons sources intracellularly in the form of lipid. Cryptococcus albidus (ATCC 10672) was obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC, Manassas, VA, USA) and a 400-bp genome library of was prepared and sequenced using Ion-torrentPGM.

datasetPresenter.name: ppluAV1007_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence for Phytopthora plurivora AV1007
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence for Phytopthora plurivora AV1007
Phytophthora plurivora is a root rot oomycete plant pathogen with a broad host range. It is responsible for the widespread decline of European beech (Fagus sylvatica) and oak species (Quercus sp.). P. plurivora strain AV1007 was originally isolated from diseased European beech (Fagus sylvatica) in MalmÃ¶, Sweden.

datasetPresenter.name: kdejCBS10117_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Kwoniella dejecticola CBS 10117.
datasetPresenter.description: Kwoniella dejecticola CBS 10117 was isolated from frass of the litchi fruit borer Conopomorpha sinensis Bradley.

datasetPresenter.name: kbesCBS10118_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Kwoniella bestiolae CBS 10118.
datasetPresenter.description: Kwoniella bestiolae CBS 10118 was isolated from frass of the litchi fruit borer Conopomorpha sinensis Bradley, Vietnam.

datasetPresenter.name: fproNRRL62905_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium proliferatum strain NRRL62905.
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium proliferatum (Gibberella intermedia) is a member of the Asian clade of the Fusarium fujikuroi species complex (FFSC) and is unusual among this group of fungi in that it can cause disease on a broad range of plants, including economically important plants such as asparagus, fig, maize, onion, palm, pine, rice and wheat. This species can also occur in plants without causing disease symptoms. F. proliferatum produces the mycotoxins fumonisins, fusaproliferin, fusarins, fusaric acid, moniliformin and beauvericin as well as the pigment bikaverin. Strain NRRL 62905 was isolated from a sample of maize kernels from the Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory at Iowa State University in Ames, Iowa USA. Whole genome shotgun sequencing project. Genome coverage 98x.

datasetPresenter.name: foxyFOSC3a_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium oxysporum FOSC 3-a.
datasetPresenter.description: Pathogenic strains of F. oxysporum have been studied for more than 100 years. The host range of these fungi is extremely broad, and includes animals, ranging from arthropods to humans, as well as plants, including a range of both gymnosperms and angiosperms. The genome of the human pathogen Fusarium oxysporum species complex 3a (FOSC 3-a) , a clinical isolate originated in Massachusetts, was sequenced using Illumina technology at coverage 195.0x. The genome was sequenced with Illumina technology at coverage 195x.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoJEC21_massSpec_Protein_Composition_Huang_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Protein composition of C. neoformans yeast and spores (B-3501A)
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomics study of vegetative cells (yeast) and spores in Cryptococcus neoformans JEC21
datasetPresenter.description: Spores are an essential cell type required for long-term survival across diverse organisms in the tree of life and are a hallmark of fungal reproduction, persistence, and dispersal. Among human fungal pathogens, spores are presumed infectious particles, but relatively little is known about this robust cell type. Nanoscale liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry was used to determine protein composition of Cryptococcus vegetative cells (yeast) and spores. Spores were purified from crosses after 6 days on V8 agar using density gradient purification. Yeast were grown on V8 agar plates for 6 days prior to harvest. Experiments were performed in triplicates.

datasetPresenter.name: akawIFO4308_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus kawachii IFO 4308.
datasetPresenter.description: This Aspergillus species is used for brewing shochu which is a traditional Japanese distilled liquor made from various raw materials, including rice, barley, sweet potato, and buckwheat. During the process of producing shochu, the fungus is grown as solid cultures on polished and steamed cereals such as rice or barley. These solid fungal cultures are referred to as 'koji'. Secreted enzymes which include a variety of polysaccharide glycoside hydrolases convert the starch present in the grains to sugars. A. kawachii is phylogenetically closely related to A. niger and both produce large amounts of citric acid, that prevents bacterial contamination which is important in the food process industry. However, unlike some strains of A. niger this fungus does not produce ochratoxin A. The A. kawachiigenome has approximately 36.5 Mbp.

datasetPresenter.name: ylipCLIB89W29_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Yarrowia lipolytica CLIB89 (W29).
datasetPresenter.description: Yarrowia lipolytica, an oleaginous yeast, is capable of accumulating significant cellular mass in lipid making it an important source of biosustainable hydrocarbon-based chemicals The oleaginous yeast Yarrowia lipolytica is an industrial model organism for production of biosustainable hydrocarbon-based chemicals. Y. lipolytica is one of the most divergent of the characterized Hemiascomycetes. Despite a genome almost twice the size of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Y. lipolytica is not thought to have undergone whole genome duplication. In addition, Y. lipolytica has more traits in common with metazoan cells than other characterized yeasts. Genome was sequenced using Illumina HiSeq 2500 and PacBio RS II technologies at coverage 2041x and 68x, respectively.

datasetPresenter.name: lproJHH5317_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Lomentospora prolificans JHH-5317.
datasetPresenter.description: Lomentospora prolificans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes a wide variety of infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent people and animals. L. prolificans is distributed throughout the world and primarily found in soil and plants. Transmission to humans is often via inhalation of the spores produced by the fungus, but occasionally it is introduced by direct traumatic inoculation. Infections can range from mild, local infections to severe and disseminated, with the latter being life-threatening. Invasive infections have been increasingly associated with hematological malignancies, transplantation, and cystic fibrosis (Rodriguez-Tudela et al. 2009). The major challenge to successful therapy is that the fungus is intrinsically resistant to almost all antifungal drugs currently available for treatment (Lackner et al. 2014). As a result, the clinical outcome of invasive infections is often fatal.

datasetPresenter.name: cgatNT10_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus gattii NT-10.
datasetPresenter.description: The major molecular genotypes of C. gattii are C. gattii(VGI), C. deuterogattii (VGII), C. bacillisporus (VGIII), and C. tetragattii (VGIV). C. gattii/VGI accounts for most Australian isolates (including the NT-10 strain and clinical isolate), while C. deuterogattii/VGII is common in South America and the American Pacific Northwest. Cryptococcus bacillisporus (previously VGIII) is prevalent in the Ibero American countries and found in India and the United States, while Cryptococcus tetragattii (previously VGIV) has been reported in India, Africa, and Central America.

datasetPresenter.name: anigN402ATCC64974_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus niger strain N402 (ATCC 64974).
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus niger is extensively used for the industrial production of organic acids and extracellular enzymes. A densely sporulating strain with short conidiophores, N402 (cspA1), was isolated following two rounds of low-dosed UV mutagenesis of about 75% survival each and was used by Bos and his colleagues as a starting strain for genetic studies. A. niger strain N402 (ATCC 64974) is a laboratory work horse strain that has been extensively used as a master strain for the generation of regulatory and structural mutants, with the aim to provide genetic insight in the molecular mechanisms underlying its extraordinary abilities.

datasetPresenter.name: cparCDC317_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Candida parapsilosis CDC 317
datasetPresenter.description: Candida parapsilosis causes infection in neonates, transplant recipients, and patients receiving parenteral nutrition. Candida parapsilosis, C. albicans, C. glabrata,and C. tropicalis account for 95% of identifiable Candida infections. The genome was sequenced using a whole genome shotgun approach where three plasmid libraries were end-sequenced by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: sbra5110_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Sporothrix brasiliensis 5110.
datasetPresenter.description: S. brasiliensis strain 5110 (ATCC MYA-4823) is an etiologic agent of sporotrichosis and was isolated from a feline skin lesion during an outbreak of sporotrichosis in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. is cat-transmitted, infects both cats and humans,and presents a high virulence in mouse models (Castro et al., 2013). The genome of S. brasiliensis was pyrosequenced to 20x coverage comprising a total of 33.2Mb.

datasetPresenter.name: sapiIHEM14462_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Scedosporium apiospermum IHEM 14462.
datasetPresenter.description: Scedosporium apiospermum is a soil-borne opportunistic pathogen rcausing cutaneous or subcutaneous mycetomas following traumatic inoculation of fungi. Species of the Scedosporium apiospermum complex are the second most frequent molds, after Aspergillus fumigatus. Scedosporium genus is also the second most frequent cause of lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients that causes ambulatory infections (bronchitis and allergic broncho-pulmonary mycoses, and disseminated life-threatening infections in immunodeficient patients).

datasetPresenter.name: fproET1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium proliferatum ET1.
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium proliferatum is a member of the Asian clade of the Fusarium (Gibberella) fujikuroi species complex (FFSC). This species produces several mycotoxins like fumonision B1, moniliformin, beauvericin and bikaverin and can live as endophyte or pathogen on a broad range of plants, including economically important plants such as asparagus, fig, maize, onion, palm, pine, rice and wheat. The isolate F. proliferatum ET1 was isolated from orchid roots and is an example for endophytic life style.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_massSpec_Geddes_Secretome_Profiling_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Secretome profiling of Cryptococcus neoformans at 16, 48, 72, 96, and 120 hr post-inoculation.
datasetPresenter.description: The pathogenic yeast Cryptococcus neoformans causes life-threatening meningoencephalitis in individuals suffering from HIV/AIDS. The cyclic-AMP/protein kinase A (PKA) signal transduction pathway regulates the production of extracellular virulence factors in C. neoformans, but the influence of the pathway on the secretome has not been investigated. In this study, quantitative proteomics was performed using galactose-inducible and glucose-repressible expression of the PKA1 gene encoding the catalytic subunit of PKA in order to identify regulated proteins in the secretome. Supernatant cultures were collected at 16, 48, 72, 120 hr post-inoculation protein extraction was done using standard protocol. For the intermediate collection point (96hr) less stringent method for protein precipitation (EtOH/acetate).

datasetPresenter.name: ssch1099-18_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Sporothrix schenckii 1099-18.
datasetPresenter.description: Sporotrichosis is one of the most frequent subcutaneous fungal infections in humans and animals caused by members of the plant-associated, dimorphic genus Sporothrix. Three of the four medically important Sporothrix species are found in Brazil: Sporothrix schenckii, Sporothrix brasiliensis, or Sporothrix globosa. The infection is mediated by the traumatic inoculation of fungal elements into the cutaneous/subcutaneous tissues or, occasionally, by inhalation followed by pulmonary lesions. The fungi are thermo-dimorphic, living as saprophytes in association with plant debris and decaying organic matter in soil, and exhibiting an invasive yeast-like form in the warm-blooded host. The genome of S. schenckii was pyrosequenced to 17x coverage comprising a total of 32.2Mb.

datasetPresenter.name: calbWO1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Candida albicans WO-1.
datasetPresenter.description:
Candida albicans is a dimorphic fungus that grows both as yeast and filamentous cells and one of the few species of the Candida genus that cause the infection candidiasis in humans. C. albicans is responsible for 50â90% of all cases of candidiasis in humans. Systemic fungal infections (fungemias) including those by C. albicans have emerged as important causes of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, organ or bone marrow transplantation). C. albicans biofilms may form on the surface of implantable medical devices. In addition, hospital-acquired infections by C. albicans have become a cause of major health concerns. About 85-95% of vaginal infections cases are responsible for physician office visits every year. Overgrowth of the fungus results in candidiasis (candidosis). Candidiasis is often observed in immunocompromised individuals, including HIV-infected patients. It commonly occurs on mucous membranes in the mouth or vagina, but may affect a number of other regions. For example, higher prevalence of colonization of C. albicans was reported in young individuals with tongue piercing, in comparison to unpierced matched individuals. To infect host tissue, the usual unicellular yeast-like form of C. albicans reacts to environmental cues and switches into an invasive, multicellular filamentous form, a phenomenon called dimorphism. In addition, an overgrowth infection is considered superinfection, usually applied when an infection become opportunistic and very resistant to antifungals. It then becomes suppressed by antibiotics. The infection is prolonged when the original sensitive strain is replaced by the antibiotic-resistant strain.

Contact CGD at candida-curator@lists.stanford.edu

datasetPresenter.name: cgatEJB2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptococcus gattii EJB2 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptococcus gattii, formerly Cryptococcus neoformans var gattii, is an encapsulated yeast found primarily in tropical and subtropical climates. Its teleomorph is Filobasidiella bacillispora, a filamentous fungus belonging to the class Tremellomycetes. EJB2 is a VGI clinical isolate from the US.
Cryptococcus gattii causes the human diseases of pulmonary cryptococcosis (lung infection), basal meningitis, and cerebral cryptococcomas. Occasionally, the fungus is associated with skin, soft tissue, lymph node, bone, and joint infections. In recent years, it has appeared in British Columbia, Canada and the Pacific Northwest. that global warming may have been a factor in its emergence in British Columbia. From 1999 through to early 2008, two hundred and sixteen people in British Columbia have been infected with C. gattii, and eight died from complications related to it. The fungus also infects animals, such as dogs, koalas and dolphins. In 2007, the fungus appeared for the first time in the United States, in Whatcom County, Washington and in April 2010 had spread to Oregon. The most recently identified strain, designated VGIIc, is particularly virulent, having proved fatal in 19 out of 218 known cases.

datasetPresenter.name: foxyrace1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense race 1 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The species Fusarium oxysporum (Fo) are ubiquitous inhabitants of soils and cause a variety of plant diseases of agricultural and ornamental plants worldwide. Oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc) is the causal agent of fusarium wilt of banana, a disease that causes serious economic losses worldwide. Foc can be divided into four physiological races: race 1, 2, 3, and 4. Race 1 is the cause of the 20th century epidemic and infects the following banana cultivars: âGros Michelâ (Musa sp. AAA group), âPomeâ, âSilkâ and âPisang Awakâ (Musa sp. AAB group). Race 2 infects the cultivar âBluggoeâ and other closely related cultivars. Race 3, on the other hand, does not infect Musa species, while race 4 can infect almost all banana cultivars.

datasetPresenter.name: foxyrace4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense race 4 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The species Fusarium oxysporum (Fo) are ubiquitous inhabitants of soils and cause a variety of plant diseases of agricultural and ornamental plants worldwide. Oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc) is the causal agent of fusarium wilt of banana, a disease that causes serious economic losses worldwide. Foc can be divided into four physiological races: race 1, 2, 3, and 4. Race 1 is the cause of the 20th century epidemic and infects the following banana cultivars: âGros Michelâ (Musa sp. AAA group), âPomeâ, âSilkâ and âPisang Awakâ (Musa sp. AAB group). Race 2 infects the cultivar âBluggoeâ and other closely related cultivars. Race 3, on the other hand, does not infect Musa species, while race 4 can infect almost all banana cultivars.

datasetPresenter.name: foxy26406_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. melonis 26406 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Horizontal chromosome transfer introduces host-specific pathogenicity among members of the Fusarium oxysporum species complex and is responsible for some of the most destructive and intractable plant diseases. The genus Fusarium is the most important group of fungal plant pathogens as it causes various diseases in essentially every economically and agriculturally important plant species. This paper reports the genome sequence of F. oxysporum f. sp. melonis 26406, a fungal pathogen that causes Fusarium wilt disease on melon (Cucumis melo).

datasetPresenter.name: hcapH143_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum H143 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Ajellomyces capsulatus (anamorph Histoplasma capsulatum) is the causative agent of histoplasmosis, an infection that chiefly affects the lungs but occasionally spreads to other organs. Ajellomyces capsulatus is a dimorphic fungus, existing as a saprophytic mycelial form in the soil and as a pathogenic yeast form in the lungs of its host.The Ajellomyces capsulatus genome is estimated at 28 Mb, organized in 7 chromosomes.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoKN99_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii KN99 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Laboratory strain KN99Î± (PMID 12933823) is nearly congenic to H99Î± but exists in both mating types and is competent to mate. Genomic DNA was isolated, libraries were prepared and sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 to obtain paired-end 101 bp reads.

datasetPresenter.name: caurB8441_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Candida auris strain B8441 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Candida auris is a pathogenic yeast that was first described in 2009 in Japan. Now C. auris presents a global health threat and outbreaks have been reported in several countries. C. auris is often resistant to multiple drugs on the market and causes invasive infections that are very difficult to treat.
The B8441 reference genome was generated by de novo assembly of PacBio reads as described alsewhere (PMID: 23644548). Assembly method: HGAP v. 3; Genome coverage: 80x; Sequencing technology: PacB.

datasetPresenter.name: asteIBT23096_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus steynii IBT 23096 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus genus is species-rich, ubiquitous, and diverse and contains key cell factories for enzyme production. Genome sequencing of the members of this genus will provide a rich resource of information about model organisms, fermenters of foodstuffs, plant pathogens, and degraders of organic matter.

datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus ochraceoroseus IBT 24754 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus genus is species-rich, ubiquitous, and diverse and contains key cell factories for enzyme production. Genome sequencing of the members of this genus will provide a rich resource of information about model organisms, fermenters of foodstuffs, plant pathogens, and degraders of organic matter.

datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus genus is species-rich, ubiquitous, and diverse and contains key cell factories for enzyme production. Genome sequencing of the members of this genus will provide a rich resource of information about model organisms, fermenters of foodstuffs, plant pathogens, and degraders of organic matter.

Genome sequencing of the members of this genus will provide a rich resource of information about model organisms, fermenters of foodstuffs, plant pathogens, and degraders of organic matter.

datasetPresenter.name: cposSilveira_massSpec_Mitchell_ProteogenomicReAnnotation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Proteogenomic Re-Annotation of Coccidioides posadasii str. Silveira
datasetPresenter.summary: Coccidioides posadasii is a dimorphic fungal pathogen that causes coccidioidomycosis in a wide range of mammalian hosts, including humans. Proteomic analysis of strain Silveira was performed to provide empirical evidence of the proteins produced in both the mycelial (CDN) and parasitic (SPH) phases.
datasetPresenter.description: Proteins present in lysates and filtrates of in vitro grown mycelia and parasitic phase spherules from C. posadasii strain Silveira were analyzed using a GeLC-MS/MS method. Method: Protein digests from gel slices were analyzed using LC-MS/MS as previously described [9]. Briefly, each digest was loaded onto a custom made 0.35ul bed OptiPak trap (Optimize Technologies, Oregon City, OR) packed with 5Âµm, 200ÃMagic C18 stationary phase. The loaded trap was washed for 4 minutes with an aqueous loading buffer of 0.2% FA and 0.05% TFA at a flow rate of 10uL/min. Following the wash, peptides were transferred onto a 35cmx100m PicoFrit column, self-packed with Agilent (Santa Clara, CA) Poroshell 120S 2.7Âµm EC-C18 stationary phase, using a Dionex UltiMateÂ® 3000 RSLC liquid chromatography system (Thermo-Fisher, Waltham, MA). Peptides were separated using a 400 nL/min LC gradient comprised of 2%-40% B in 0-70 min. Mobile phase A was 2% ACN in water with 0.2% FA and mobile phase B was ACN/isopropanol/water (80/10/10 by volume) with 0.2% FA. Eluting peptides were analyzed using a QExactive Plus mass spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher). The instrument was configured to operate in data-dependent mode by collecting MS1 data at 70,000 resolving power (measured at m/z 200) with an AGC value of 1E6 over a m/z range of 360-2000, using lock masses from background polysiloxanes at m/z 371.10123 and 446.12002. Precursors were fragmented with normalized collision energy (NCE) of 28, fragments measured at 17,500 resolving power and a fixed first mass of 140. Resulting tandem MS/MS were collected on the top 20 precursor masses present in each MS1 using an AGC value of 1E5, max ion fill time of 50ms, and an isolation window of 1.5 Da.

datasetPresenter.name: hcapG217B_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum strain G217B Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Ajellomyces capsulatus (anamorph Histoplasma capsulatum) is the causative agent of histoplasmosis, an infection that chiefly affects the lungs but occasionally spreads to other organs. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungal pathogen normally found in a filamentous mycelial form in the soil of endemic regions. Upon inhalation by a mammalian host fungal cells convert to pathogenic yeast form capable of intracellular growth within macrophages.

The Ajellomyces capsulatus genome is estimated at 43 Mb, organized in 7 chromosomes. Note that the Hc G217B genome is considerably larger than the Hc G186AR genome due to more repetitive content, mainly LTR transposons. Transposon content is known to vary quite a bit among Histoplasma strains in the wild based on genomic DNA denaturation curves (PMID 9375491).

datasetPresenter.name: foxy54006_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense tropical race 4 54006 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium wilt or Panama disease of banana is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc) and it is a destructive disease of banana. Tropical race 4 (TR4), first identified in Southeast Asia in 1992, is a variant of Foc that has spread throughout the Southeast Asia and also affect the Cavendish clones, which are the main cultivars of banana exported worldwide. There is a huge concern that TR4 will further disseminate in Africa and Latin America, thereby threatening banana-growing regions worldwide.

datasetPresenter.name: foxyFo47_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium oxysporum Fo47 Genome Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The endophytic strain of Fusarium oxysporum strain Fo47 is effective in protecting tomato and cucumber plants against Fusarium wilt disease and Pythium ultimum, respectively. This nonpathogenic strain of Fusarium oxysporum was initially isolated by Alabouvette et al. (1985, 1996) from a suppressive soil in ChÃ¢aurenard (France).

datasetPresenter.name: hcapH88_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Histoplasma capsulatum H88 (Ajellomyces capsulatus H88)
datasetPresenter.description: Ajellomyces capsulatus (anamorph Histoplasma capsulatum) is the causal agent of Histoplasmosis, also known as Darling's disease. Found throughout the world commonly in bat and bird droppings, the disease is contracted by breathing in the fungal spores. Most people do not display any symptoms and are unaware they are infected, but in immunocompromised individuals the disease can spread from the lungs to other organs of the body and can be fatal if left untreated. It is most prevalent in the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys. It was discovered by Samuel Taylor Darling in 1906.

datasetPresenter.name: prubWisconsin54-1255_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Penicillium rubens Wisconsin 54-1255
datasetPresenter.description: Penicillium chrysogenum commonly inhabits a wide variety of environments and it is found naturally in moist soils with abundant carbon and nitrogen sources. P. chrysogenum is also an important industrial workhorse used for production of penicillin (penicillinV and penicillinG).

link.text: EnsemblFungi Penicillium rubens Wisconsin 54-1255 Assembly and Gene Annotation

datasetPresenter.name: cgatIND107_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus gattii VGIV IND107 (Cryptococcus tetragattii IND107)
datasetPresenter.description: Genus Filobasidiella contains approximately 38 Cryptococcus species. A few are pathogenic and constitute the pathogenic Cryptococcus species cluster. Two of the species, Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii, are the casual agents of the majority of human and animal cryptococcosis. These infections most commonly occur in immunocompromised hosts, however infection of immunocompetent hosts has also been reported. Cryptococcal disease is acquired via inhalation of haploid yeast or basidiospores from the environment. This genus typically reproduces asexually as haploid, encapsulated budding yeast, but may also be dispersed by means of sexually produced basidiospores. Its mating type locus (MAT) contains more than 20 genes. Usually MAT-a and MAT-alpha cells are involved in mating. However same-sex mating between two MAT-alpha cells has also been observed. Sexual reproduction can play an important role in contributing to virulence of the pathogen. Based on the differences in capsule polysaccharides, Cryptococcus is traditionally subdivided into 5 serotypes - A, B, C, D and AD. The polysaccharide capsule protects the fungus from the host's immune system and is considered a key factor in determining the virulence of cryptococcal infections and disease. Another characteristic that can be used to subdivide the Cryptococcus species is unique molecular types (genotypes). Recent work has distinguished Cryptococcus gattii (teleomorph: Filobasidiella bacillispora (aka Cryptococcus neoformans var. gatti) from other Cryptococcus neoformans variants (such as v. neoformans and v. grubii) and now it is recognized as a distinct species. It is presented by serotype B and serotype C. Cryptococcus gattii is limited mainly to tropical and sub-tropical climates, although it has also been found in the temperate Pacific Northwest endemic area. Within the Cryptococcus gattii there are four recognized molecular types (genotypes): VGI, VGII, VGIII, and VGIV. It has been proposed to recognize these genotypes as different taxa.VGII is considered a high virulence genotype because it has been found during cryptococcosis outbreaks in Vancouver Island, Canada. Infections have been observed in a variety of domestic animals and marine animals as well as humans. Most cases presented as a pneumonia-like disease in healthy individuals. The majority of the isolates belong to subtype VGIIa. The Cryptococcus gattii genome is approximately 20 Mb, organized in 14 chromosomes. The Cryptococcus gattiiVGIV IND107 whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession ATAM00000000. This version of the project (01) has the accession number ATAM01000000, and consists of sequences ATAM01000001-ATAM01000098. Please be aware that the annotation is done automatically with little or no manual curation.

datasetPresenter.name: cgatCA1873_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus gattii VGIII CA1873 (Cryptococcus bacillisporus CA1873)
datasetPresenter.description: Genus Filobasidiella contains approximately 38 Cryptococcus species. A few are pathogenic and constitute the pathogenic Cryptococcus species cluster. Two othe species, Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii, are the casual agents of the majority of human and animal cryptococcosis. This genus typically reproduces asexually as haploid, encapsulated budding yeast, but may also be dispersed by means of sexually produced basidiospores. Its mating type locus (MAT) contains more than 20 genes. Usually MAT-a and MAT-alpha cells are involved in mating. However same-sex mating between two MAT-alpha cells has also been observed. Sexual reproduction can play an important role in contributing to virulence of the pathogen. Based on the differences in capsule polysaccharides, Cryptococcus is traditionally subdivided into 5 serotypes - A, B, C, D and AD. The polysaccharide capsule protects the fungus from the host's immune system and is considered a key factor in determining the virulence of cryptococcal infections and disease. Another characteristic that can be used to subdivide the Cryptococcus species is unique molecular types (genotypes). Recent work has distinguished Cryptococcus gattii (teleomorph: Filobasidiella bacillispora (aka Cryptococcus neoformans var. gatti) from other Cryptococcus neoformans variants (such as v. neoformans and v. grubii) and now it is recognized as a distinct species. It is presented by serotype B and serotype C. Cryptococcus gattii is limited mainly to tropical and sub-tropical climates, although it has also been found in the temperate Pacific Northwest endemic area. Within the Cryptococcus gattii there are four recognized molecular types (genotypes): VGI, VGII, VGIII, and VGIV. It has been proposed to recognize these genotypes as different taxa.VGII is considered a high virulence genotype because it has been found during cryptococcosis outbreaks in Vancouver Island, Canada. Infections have been observed in a variety of domestic animals and marine animals as well as humans. Most cases presented as a pneumonia-like disease in healthy individuals. The majority of the isolates belong to subtype VGIIa. The Cryptococcus gattii genome is approximately 20 Mb, organized in 14 chromosomes. The Cryptococcus gattii CA1873 whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession ASCQ00000000. This version of the project (01) has the accession number ASCQ01000000, and consists of sequences ASCQ01000001-ASCQ01000094. Please be aware that the annotation is done automatically with little or no manual curation.

datasetPresenter.name: moryBR32_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Magnaporthe oryzae BR32
datasetPresenter.description: Magnaporthe oryzae (synonym Pyricularia oryzae) is an important plant pathogen originally isolated from rice but adapted to infect various plant hosts. 2015-2016 wheat blast outbreaks in Bangladesh and India were cause by an M. oryzae isolate adapted to infect wheat. The BR32 isolate (from Brazil, pathogenic to Triticum sp.) was sequenced at the GÃ©noscope (Centre National de SÃ©quenÃ§age, Evry, France) using both Solexa and Titanium technologies. One simple Solexa_GAIIX run (75 bp) and two mate-pair Titanium runs (8 kb) were performed. Assembly was performed at the GÃ©noscope using Newbler 2.6 assembler that allows combining both Solexa and Titanium information (454). Genome total assembly size for BR32 isolate was 41.9Mb with 55X coverage, mitochondrial genome size - 34,588bp.

datasetPresenter.name: uree1704_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Uncinocarpus reesii 1704.
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Uncinocarpus reesii 1704. The non-pathogenic fungus Uncinocarpus reesii is the closest known relative of the pathogenic species Coccidioides immitis and Coccidioides posadasii, with an estimated evolutionary distance to Coccidioides immitis of 20-30 million years. Uncinocarpus reesii is an environmental saprophyte. It has an identified sexual stage.The haploid genome of Uncinocarpus reesii is approximately 30 Mb. The U. reesii genome coverage is 14.4X with GC content being 48.7%.

datasetPresenter.name: ztriIPO323_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Zymoseptoria tritici IPO323
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Zymoseptoria tritici IPO323 (genbank synonym: Mycosphaerella graminicola IPO323) Z. tritici is the causal agent of septoria tritici blotch, which is a common and economically important disease of wheat worldwide. The pathogen is a haploid hemibiotrophic ascomycete with both filamentous and yeast-like growth. The genome of the strain IPO323 has been completely finished and contains 21 chromosomes. Twenty of the 21 chromosomes are sequenced from telomere to telomere. The genome show high plasticity, it has been determined that eight of the 21 chromosomes could be lost with no visible effect on the fungus and thus are dispensable. Also has the largest chromosome number with the greatest size range recorded among filamentous ascomycetes.The size of the haploid nuclear genome is estimated at 39.6 Mb and the complete mitochondrial genome is 43,960bp.

datasetPresenter.name: clusATCC42720_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Clavispora lusitaniae ATCC 42720
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Clavispora lusitaniae ATCC 42720 Candida species are the most common cause of opportunistic fungal infection worldwide. Candida lucitanea is heterothallic emerging pathogen with a genome size of 12.1Mb and 44.5% CG content.

datasetPresenter.name: abraCBS101740_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus brasiliensis CBS 101740
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Aspergillus brasiliensis CBS 101740, a member of black aspergilli group. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 156.8x; genome size: 36Mb; and GC content is 50.5%.

datasetPresenter.name: azonCBS506.65_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus zonatus CBS506.65
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Aspergillus zonatus CBS506.65, now renamed as Penicilliopsis zonata CBS 506.65 A. zonatus was originally isolated from tropical forest soil samples collected in Costa Rica. This species known to produce metabolites which overlap with the penicillia.

datasetPresenter.name: awenDTO134E9_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus wentii DTO 134E9
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Aspergillus wentii DTO 134E9 is commonly used for enzyme production on industrial scale. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 95x; genome size: 31Mb; and GC content is 48.0%.

datasetPresenter.name: averCBS583.65_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus versicolor CBS 583.65
datasetPresenter.description: A. versicolor is a resilient ubiquitous fungus closely related to A. nidulans. It is commonly found in damp indoor environments. This species can colonise food products and are known to produce sterigmatocystin - aflatoxin-related mycotoxin. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 178.1x; genome size: 33Mb; and GC content is 50.1%.

datasetPresenter.name: atubCBS134.48_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus tubingensis CBS 134.48
datasetPresenter.description: A. tubingensis is ubiquitous black aspergilli fungus commonly found in the airways of patients with lung disease. This species also are used in industry for production of enzymes (amylase, lipase, acid phosphatase, and others) organic acids (citric and ascorbic acids). The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 155.5x; genome size: 35Mb; and GC content is 49.2%.

datasetPresenter.name: asydCBS593.65_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus sydowii CBS 593.65
datasetPresenter.description: A. sydowii is an emerging fungal disease that threatens marine ecosystems. It has been reported to causes aspergillosis in sea fan corals in Caribbean, Colombian, and Ecuadorian coral reef ecosystems. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 95.1x; genome size: 34Mb; and GC content is 50.0%.

datasetPresenter.name: alucCBS106.47_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus luchuensis CBS 106.47
datasetPresenter.description: A. luchuensis, also known as A. acidus and A. foetidus, is a member of black aspergilli group. This is an important industrial fungus that is commonly used for awamori, shochu, makgeolli and other food and beverage fermentations. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 175.9x; genome size: 37Mb; and GC content is 49.1%.

datasetPresenter.name: aglaCBS516.65_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus glaucus CBS516.65
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus glaucus is ubiquitous fungus found in arctic regions and outdor in the winter. It can grow in low moisture conditions, on leather, grains, meat, and wool and commonly isolated from soil, house dust, and plants. The genome was sequenced using a combination of 454 and Sanger platforms and then assembled with Newbler (Roche). Genome coverage: 175.9x; genome size: 30Mb; and GC content is 49.4%.

datasetPresenter.name: afumA1163_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus fumigatus A1163 APO3.
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus fumigatus is ubiquitous airborne saprophytic fungi that has important role in carbon and nitrogen recycling. It is also a human and animal pathogen that can cause aspergillosis and invasive mold infection leading to high mortality rate in immunocompromised patients.

datasetPresenter.name: anidFGSCA4_massSpec_Marten_phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus nidulans Phosphoproteome
datasetPresenter.description: Survey of the A. nidulans strain A1166 phosphoproteome. To enrich phosphopeptides from complex cell lysate, metal-oxide affinity chromatography with TiO2 resin was used, followed by sample fractionation via ultralong, RP gradients. Data were acquired using the higher-energy collisional dissociation (HCD) method of fragmentation.

datasetPresenter.name: afumAf293_massSpec_Suh_stageSpecific_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus fumigatus early development proteome
datasetPresenter.description: A shotgun proteomics approach was used to discover patterns of protein abundance in early fungal development (dormant conidia, isotropically expanding conidia, hyphae in which germ tube emergence has just begun, and pre-septation hyphae). Cells were harvested at 0, 4, 6, and 8 hrs. Aspergillus fumigatus strain CEA10 proteome searched against A. fumigatus Af293. This dataset displays cumulative findings across all time points. For quantitative data refer to the Quantitative Mass Spec. Evidence search option.

link.text: Access data from EMBL European Bioinformatics Institute

datasetPresenter.name: afumAf293_quantitativeMassSpec_Suh_stageSpecific_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus fumigatus quantitative stage-specific proteome
datasetPresenter.description: A Quantitative shotgun proteomics approach was used to discover patterns of protein abundance in early fungal development (dormant conidia, isotropically expanding conidia, hyphae in which germ tube emergence has just begun, and pre-septation hyphae). Cells were harvested at 0, 4, 6, and 8 hrs. Alkaline cell extraction method was used to enrich for glycan-linked cell wall proteins.Aspergillus fumigatus strain CEA10 proteome searched against A. fumigatus Af293.

link.text: Access data from EMBL European Bioinformatics Institute

datasetPresenter.name: ffujIMI58289_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium fujikuroi IMI 58289.
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation of Fusarium fujikuroi IMI 58289. This fungus produces secondary metabolites of biotechnological interest, such as gibberellins, bikaverin, and carotenoids. The high production of gibberellin causes super elongation of rice seedlings and is called bakanae disease.

datasetPresenter.name: aacuATCC16872_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus aculeatus ATCC 16872.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus aculeatus is a ubiquitous species that is commonly isolated from soil and rotting fruit. Like other black-spored Aspergillus species, morphological criteria like color, shape, size, and ornamentation of conidia have been used to classify strains. However, the black aspergilli vary significantly in their morphological and physiological characteristics, and unambiguous identification of an isolate requires molecular and biochemical identification techniques. Owing to its ability to rapidly degrade plant cell walls, A. aculeatus isolates have been used to produce a number of important industrial enzymes (cellulases, hemicellulases, proteases) that are used commercially in the food and feed industries. The biochemical and catalytic properties of several extracellular glycosyl hydrolases from A. aculeatus have been studied in detail. In addition, several A. aculeatus polysaccharide degrading enzymes have studied at the structural level by X-ray crystallography.

This annotation was produced by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based, protein-based, and ab initio gene predictors. After filtering for protein similarity and cDNA support, a total of 10845 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.

datasetPresenter.name: aastAPO3_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aphanomyces astaci APO3.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aphanomyces astaci is a mold-like parasite that infects crayfish.

This Aphanomyces astaci assembly was produced by the Broad Institute as part of the Aphanomyces WGS initiative. It was sequenced using Illumina reads at 107x coverage.

datasetPresenter.name: acan2VRR_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Albugo candida 2VRR.
datasetPresenter.description:
Albugo candida is a biotrophic oomycete that parasitizes various species of Brassicaceae, causing a disease (white blister rust) with remarkable convergence in behaviour to unrelated rusts of basidiomycete fungi.

A. candida 2VRR was sequenced using pyrosequencing to a 20 Ã shotgun coverage. Assembly of the shotgun data yielded 33.9 Mbps in 2,359 contigs of at least 500 bps with an N50 of 77 kb. After scaffolding the assembly was resolved to 252 scaffolds covering 34.5 Mbps with an N50 of 375 kb.

De novo gene prediction was accomplished with glimmerHMM and GENEID, trained specifically for A. candida using cDNA data. Evidence Modeler was used to predict gene models. Validation of the predicted genes in the Ac2VRR genome was achieved using RNA-Seq data from sporangiospores. RNA-Seq data was aligned to the genome using Bowtie, TopHat, and Cufflinks.

datasetPresenter.name: acarITEM5010_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus carbonarius ITEM 5010.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus carbonarius resembles A. niger in many features, and indeed the two species are very closely related. A. carbonarius differs from A. niger most notably in the production of larger spores, although other minor morphological differences exist. The available information on its physiology indicates a broad similarity to A. niger. Recently, black aspergilli, mainly Aspergillus carbonarius and members of the Aspergillus niger aggregate, have been described as a main possible sources of ochratoxin (OTA) contamination in grapes from Argentina and Brazil, France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Australia as well as in dried vine fruits from different origins. Strong evidence of the contribution of A. carbonarius to the OTA contamination of wine has been also reported. Ochratoxin A is a highly harmful metabolite classified in 1993 by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC, 1993) as a possible human carcinogenic toxin (group 2B).

Annotation v3 (14 Dec 2009) is a consensus gene set predicted by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based , protein-based, and ab initio gene modelers. After filtering for homology and expression support, a total of 11624 genes were structurally and functionally annotated. Assembly v3 (14 Dec 2009) is a 'hybrid' assembly of 454 and Sanger, DNA reads improved by the JGI Finishing Pipeline. 963 scaffolds and 36.3 Mbp were assembled.

datasetPresenter.name: aclaNRRL1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus clavatus NRRL 1.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus clavatus is a rarely pathogenic fungus that is evolutionarily close to two major pathogenic fungi, Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus terreus. Aspergillus clavatus is very allergenic and can produce the toxin patulin, which may be associated with disease in humans and animals. This filamentous fungus is found in soil and animal manure.

Aspergillus clavatus (strain NRRL1) was sequenced by TIGR with funding provided by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) at 11.4x coverage using whole genome shotgun sequencing. Version 3 of the assembly consists of 231 contigs in 143 scaffolds. It has undergone automated annotation.

datasetPresenter.name: aflaNRRL3357_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357.
datasetPresenter.description:
The haploid filamentous fungus Aspergillus flavus causes approximately 30% of the cases of aspergillosis, a serious human disease. It also produces the highly carcinogenic mycotoxin aflatoxin. Infestations of grains by this fungus results in large agricultural and economic losses. The Aspergillus flavus genome has an estimated size of 36 Mb, organized in 8 chromosomes.

The Aspergillus flavus genome was sequenced and annotated by JCVI and the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Aspergillus Comparative Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: afumAf293_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus fumigatus Af293.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus fumigatus is exceptional among microorganisms in being both a primary and opportunistic pathogen as well as a major allergen. Its conidia production is prolific, and so human respiratory tract exposure is almost constant. A. fumigatus is isolated from human habitats and vegetable compost heaps. In immunocompromised individuals, the incidence of invasive infection can be as high as 50% and the mortality rate is often about 50% (ref. 2). The interaction of A. fumigatus and other airborne fungi with the immune system is increasingly linked to severe asthma and sinusitis.

The Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 genome was sequenced and annotated by JCVI/Sanger Institute/Institut Pasteur. Additional annotation was added by the Broad Institute. It was obtained from the Aspergillus Genome Database (AspGD.org).
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Aspergillus Comparative Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: ainvNJM9701_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aphanomyces invadans NJM9701.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aphanomyces invadans is a fish pathogen which causes epizootic ulcerative syndrome or red spot disease.

The Aphanomyces invadans assembly was produced by the Broad Institute as part of the Aphanomyces WGS initiative. It was sequenced using Illumina reads at 138x coverage.

datasetPresenter.name: alaiNc14_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Albugo laibachii Nc14.
datasetPresenter.description:
Albugo laibachii is a pathogen of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. This pathogen and Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis are regularly found to co-infect plants and sporulate on the same leaf. A remarkable consequence of infection by Albugo sp. is enhanced host plant susceptibility to other parasites to which the host is resistant in the absence of Albugo infection, and also impairment of cell death mechanisms.

This assembly was sequenced by the Sainsbury Laboratory and provided by Ensembl. The A. laibachii Nc14 genome was sequenced using Illumina 76-bp paired reads with ~240-fold coverage and assembled via an assembly pipeline, which used Velvet as primary assembler and Minimus as meta-assembler.

datasetPresenter.name: amacATCC38327_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Allomyces macrogynus ATCC 38327.
datasetPresenter.description:
Allomyces macrogynus is found worldwide, particularly in aquatic environments of tropical regions. It alternates between isomorphic sporophytic sexual and gametophytic asexual cycles of growth, producing three forms of uniflagellated cells: mitospores (zoospores), meiospores, and male and female gametes. When encysting, these flagellated cells withdraw their flagellum. Bipolar spore germination then leads to the development of a rhizoidal system, and a thallus that branches into hyphae that are separated by pseudoseptae.

The Broad Institute produced this assembly from whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing at 11.39X coverage.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Origins of Multicellularity Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: anidFGSCA4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus nidulans FGSC A4.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus nidulans is an important model organism for studies in cell biology. This fungus has also been used to express mammalian genes. Aspergillosis, a clinical infection that can lead to an allergic response, a growth, or invasive disease, is caused by fungi of the genus Aspergillus, most commonly Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus flavus but also Aspergillus nidulans and others. Due to the significance of Aspergillus fungi as human pathogens, the Aspergillus nidulans genome is important to study, as it will assist in understanding the biology, host interactions, and pathogenicity of these organisms, as well as aid in vaccine and drug development.

The A. nidulans genome was sequenced by the Broad Institute. It was obtained from the Aspergillus Genome Database (AspGD.org).
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Aspergillus Comparative Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: anigATCC1015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus niger is used in industry to produce citric acid, pharmaceuticals, enzymes, and food products. The species shows great phenotypic diversity and is found globally, both as marine and terrestrial strains, producing both organic acids and hydrolytic enzymes in high amounts, and some isolates exhibit pathogenicity.

The Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 genome was annotated by JGI and made available on Genbank.

datasetPresenter.name: anigCBS513-88_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus niger CBS 513.88.
datasetPresenter.description:
Industrial enzyme-producing A. niger strain that was sequenced by Integrated Genomics. It is a derivative of NRRL 3122 (ATCC 22343, CBS 115989) that was isolated after mutagenesis and selection for improved glucoamylase production.

The Aspergillus niger CBS513-88 genome was sequenced by Gene Alliance for DSM, The Netherlands. It was obtained from the Aspergillus Genome Database (AspGD.org).

datasetPresenter.name: aterNIH2624_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus terreus NIH2624.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus terreus is a filamentous fungus that produces clinically relevant secondary metabolites -- statins. Statins are cholesterol-lowering drugs that have been widely used in the past decade for the prevention of heart disease. Of the five statins currently prescribed by physicians, three (pravastatin, simvastatin, and lovastatin) are derived by fermentation by Aspergillus terreus. In addition, this fungus can produce the toxins patulin and citrinin, which may cause toxicoses in humans and other animals and is associated with aspergillosis of the lungs and/or disseminated aspergillosis.

The Aspergillus terreus NIH2624 genome was sequenced and annotated by JCVI and the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Aspergillus Comparative Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: bdenJEL423_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis JEL423.
datasetPresenter.description:
Batrachochytrium is a pathogen of amphibians implicated as a primary causative agent of amphibian declines. This recently emerging pathogen was identified in 1998 as the cause of amphibian deaths in Australia and Central America. More recently, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been implicated in population declines of frog species in North America, South America, Europe and Africa. This fungus invades the top layers of skin cells and causes thickening of the keratinized layer. As a representative of the Chytridiomycota (chytrids), the sequence of B. dendrobatidis is the first in this largely uncharacterized phylum of fungi.

The Broad Institute sequenced the diploid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis strain JEL423 genome at 7.4X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The current assembly (Assembly 1) consists of 348 nuclear genome contigs in 69 supercontigs, and 3 mitochondrial genome contigs in 1 supercontig. It was made public in September 2006.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Candida albicans SC5314.
datasetPresenter.description:
Candida albicans, a diploid sexual fungus, is the causal agent of opportunistic infections in humans, the most common being oral and vaginal infections. Systemic fungal infections have emerged as important causes of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, organ or bone marrow transplantation). In addition, hospital-related infections in patients not previously considered at risk (e.g., patients on an intensive care unit) have become a cause of major health concern.

The C. albicans SC5314 genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly was done by the Stanford Genome Technology Center and the Biotechnology Research Institute of the National Research Council of Canada. It was obtained from the Candida Genome Database (CGD.org).

Contact CGD at candida-curator@lists.stanford.edu

datasetPresenter.name: ccinokay7-130_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Coprinopsis cinerea (Coprinus cinereus) okayama7#130.
datasetPresenter.description:
Coprinopsis cinerea, also known as Coprinus cinereus, is a multicellular basidiomycete that undergoes a complete sexual cycle, including typical mushroom formation. Extensive genetic and molecular analyses of this organism can be performed due to its easy cultivation on defined minimal media, making it a great model for studying development and regulation in multicellular organisms. The Coprinopsis cinerea genome is estimated at 37.5 Mb, organized in 13 chromosomes. Over 100 markers involved in mating type, hyphal growth, fruit body morphogenesis, and DNA repair have been assigned to 10 linkage groups. RFLP and RAPD markers are widely used.

The Coprinopsis cinerea reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coprinopsis cinerea strain okayama 7#130 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad institute. Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from 4kb & 10kb plasmids and 40kb Fosmids.

datasetPresenter.name: cgatWM276_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus gattii WM276.
datasetPresenter.description:
C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.

Cryptococcus gattii was sequenced and assembled by the Kronstad Lab at the University of British Columbia.

datasetPresenter.name: cglaCBS138_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Candida glabrata CBS 138.
datasetPresenter.description:
Candida glabrata is the second most frequent causative agent of human candidiasis, after Candida albicans. C. glabrata is a human commensal yeast in healthy individuals but with widespread use of immunosuppressive therapy and broad-spectrum antimycotic treatments it has been increasingly identified as the causal agent of candidiases. C. glabrata is innately resistant to fluconazole, a triazole fungicide frequently used to control Candida infections. In contrast to other Candida species, C. glabrata is not dimorphic, so it exist as blastoconidia when pathogenic or commensal under all environmental conditions. C. glabrata is haploid and has no known sexual cycle. Its closest relative is the non-pathogenic Nakaseomyces delphensis which does have a sexual cycle. A survey of the C. glabrata genome revealed that several genes involved with mating and meiosis are present so this fungus may possibly have a cryptic sexual stage. The Candida glabrata genome is approximately 12.3 Mb, organized in 13 chromosomes.

Candida glabrata was sequenced by Genolevures. It was obtained from the Candida Genome Database (CGD.org).

Contact CGD at candida-curator@lists.stanford.edu
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added

datasetPresenter.name: cimmH538-4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Coccidioides immitis H538.4.
datasetPresenter.description:
Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic soil fungus that is morphologically identical to, but genetically distinct from, Coccidioides posadasii. Both fungi cause the disease coccidioidomycosis, also known as valley fever. The rate of infection varies from year to year, but on average, 100,000 people are infected in the United States annually. A low percentage of infections are serious, even fatal; problems are more likely in people with poor immune systems. Coccidioides immitis has been classified as an organism with bioterrorist potential. It is a model for studying the evolutionary biology of pathogenic fungi.

Coccidioides immitis was sequenced by the Broad Institute using a whole-genome shotgun method with 3.41x coverage. The resulting assembly was annotated using automatic methods.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Coccidioides group Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: cimmRS_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Coccidioides immitis RS.
datasetPresenter.description:
Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic soil fungus that is morphologically identical to, but genetically distinct from, Coccidioides posadasii. Both fungi cause the disease coccidioidomycosis, also known as valley fever. The rate of infection varies from year to year, but on average, 100,000 people are infected in the United States annually. A low percentage of infections are serious, even fatal; problems are more likely in people with poor immune systems. Coccidioides immitis has been classified as an organism with bioterrorist potential. It is a model for studying the evolutionary biology of pathogenic fungi.

The Coccidioides immitis genome was sequenced by the Broad Institute using a whole-genome shotgun method with 14.41x coverage. It was annotated using automatic methods.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Coccidioides group Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT

datasetPresenter.name: cneoB-3501A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans B-3501A.
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that may cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Often found in soils contaminated with bird feces, C. neoformans enters its host through the lungs via inhalation of spores. In healthy individuals the infection is usually controlled and asymptomatic, but in immunocompromised hosts the fungus can spread via the blood to infect the central nervous system and cause meningitis that is uniformly fatal if untreated. Few antifungal agents exist and drug-resistant strains are emerging.

C. neoformans var. neoformans strain B-3501A was sequenced and annotated by the Stanford Genome Technology Center. It is provided by Genbank.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99.
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that may cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Often found in soils contaminated with bird feces, C. neoformans enters its host through the lungs via inhalation of spores. In healthy individuals the infection is usually controlled and asymptomatic, but in immunocompromised hosts the fungus can spread via the blood to infect the central nervous system and cause meningitis that is uniformly fatal if untreated. Few antifungal agents exist and drug-resistant strains are emerging.

C. neoformans var. grubii H99 genome was assembled and annotated by Fred Dietrich et al., from Duke University. It was further curated and provided by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoJEC21_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans JEC21.
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that may cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Often found in soils contaminated with bird feces, C. neoformans enters its host through the lungs via inhalation of spores. In healthy individuals the infection is usually controlled and asymptomatic, but in immunocompromised hosts the fungus can spread via the blood to infect the central nervous system and cause meningitis that is uniformly fatal if untreated. Few antifungal agents exist and drug-resistant strains are emerging.

C. neoformans var. neoformans JEC21 genome was annotated by TIGR and submitted to Genbank.

datasetPresenter.name: cposC735deltSOWgp_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans JEC21.
datasetPresenter.description:
Although morphologically identical to Coccidioides immitis, Coccidioides posadassi (formerly known as non-California Coccidioides immitis) represents a divergent, genetically recombining monophyletic clade (Fisher et al. Mycologia 94:73-84, 2002). C. posadassii also differs phenotypically, this fungus has significantly slower growth rates on high-salt media when compared with C. immitis. Both fungi are dimorphic and cause the disease coccidioidomycosis, also known as valley fever.

Reference sequence provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coccidiodes posadasii transgenic strain C735 delta SOWgp genome sequence submitted to INSDC by the J. Craig Venter Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium graminearum (Gibberella zeae) PH-1.
datasetPresenter.description:
The fungus Gibberella zeae (anamorph Fusarium graminearum) is the causal agent of head blight (scab) in wheat and barley. This disease has had a major impact on U.S. agriculture and society during the past decade. Gibberella zeae also produces vomitoxin, a mycotoxin that poses a serious health hazard to humans and animals.

The de novo assembly using a sequencing depth of 85x coverage created a F. graminearum genome of 36,563,796 bp in length, assembled into four chromosomes and a mitochondrial genome of 95,638 bp in length.
datasetPresenter.history: new-submitter, re-sequenced, re-annotated, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: foxy4287_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici 4287.
datasetPresenter.description:
Fusarium oxysporum is a ubiquitous soil fungus with no observed sexual state causing vascular wilt and root rot disease in a broad range of plants within the asterids, rosids and commelinids. Based on host specificity F. oxysporum isolates have been grouped into formae specials (f. sp.) and some are further subdivided into pathogenic races. For example isolates that cause vascular wilt of tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum) are called Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici and the first genome sequenced within the Fusarium oxysporum species complex (FOSC) was that of F. oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici race 2 and vegetative compatibility group (VCG) 0030. Without disease control, FOSC members have the potential to cause severe crop losses in fields, plantations and glasshouses.

Fusarium oxysporum draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: fver7600_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Fusarium verticillioides 7600.
datasetPresenter.description:
The fungus Gibberella moniliformis, also known as Fusarium verticillioides, infects maize worldwide. Under certain environmental conditions, it causes kernel and ear rot of maize, a disease that can result in significant crop and economic losses. Gibberella moniliformis also produces carcinogenic fumonisin mycotoxins. Maize that is contaminated with fumonisins can cause a variety of diseases in humans and animals if it is consumed.

Fusarium verticillioides genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: haraEmoy2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis Emoy2.
datasetPresenter.description:
Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis causes downy mildew disease in a variety of species in the Brassicaceae family, such as oilseed rape and broccoli. The disease causes economically important damage by killing seedlings or decreasing the quality of produce. This species contains a complex of subspecies, each with a more specific plant host range.

Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome sequenced and assembled at WashU genome center and Sainsbury lab and annotated at VBI.

datasetPresenter.name: mcirCBS277-49_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Mucor circinelloides f. lusitanicus CBS 277.49.
datasetPresenter.description:
Mucor circinelloides is a dimorphic fungus belonging to the Zygomycete class that has been studied in the laboratory for 35 years. Researchers have been attracted to it mainly because of its dimorphism, light responses, high capacity for accumulating lipids, anaerobic and aerobic production of ethanol and gene silencing mechanisms (RNAi). In the last few years the rate of knowledge acquisition in these fields has grown exponentially, and it is expected to grow even more in the future, due to the increasing number of molecular tools available to manipulate its genome, which allows the functional analysis of its genes. Mucor circinelloides is the fungus with the broadest molecular tool repertoire within the Zygomycota phylum. This includes genetic transformation using self-replicative plasmids, integrative transformation mediated by Agrobacterium, generation of knockout mutants and use of RNAi-based procedures to suppress gene function.

Assembly v2 (28 Dec 2009) is an improved assembly produced by the JGI Finishing Pipeline. 26 scaffolds and 36.6 Mbp were assembled. Annotation v2 (28 Dec 2009) is a consensus gene set predicted by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based, protein-based, and ab initio gene modelers, as well as Annotation v1 genes mapped onto the v2 scaffolds. After filtering for homology and expression support, a total of 11719 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.

datasetPresenter.name: mgloCBS7966_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Malassezia globosa CBS 7966.
datasetPresenter.description:
Members of the genus Malassezia (formerly Pityrosporum) are lipophilic or lipid-dependent yeasts that are part of the normal cutaneous microflora. Considered opportunistic pathogens, they can cause systemic infection in neonates and are associated with multiple human skin disorders, including pityriasis versicolor (PV), psoriasis, atopic dermatitis (AD), seborrheic dermatitis (SD), dandruff, and Malassezia folliculitis. Malassezia globosa corresponds to the original description of Pityrosporum orbiculare and to the former serovar B of Malassezia furfur. It is commonly isolated from human scalp, and its mycelial form has been reported to cause PV.

The Malassezia globosa reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Malassezia globosa strain CBS 7966 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by The Procter & Gamble Company.

datasetPresenter.name: mlar98AG31_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Melampsora larici-populina 98AG31.
datasetPresenter.description:
The poplar leaf rust fungus Melampsora is the most devastating and widespread pathogen of poplars, and has limited the use of poplars for environmental and wood production goals in many parts of the world. Almost all known poplar cultivars are susceptible to Melampsora laricis-populina, and new virulent strains are continuously developing. This disease therefore has a strong potential impact on current and future poplar plantations used for production of forest products (principally pulp and consolidated wood products), carbon sequestration, biofuels production, and bioremediation.

The assembly release version 1.0 of whole genome shotgun reads was constructed with the Arachne assembler using paired end sequencing reads at a coverage of ~6.79X. It was annotated by JGI using automated methods.

datasetPresenter.name: mory70-15_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Magnaporthe oryzae 70-15.
datasetPresenter.description:
Magnaporthe oryzae (asexual state: Pyricularia oryzae), previously known as Magnaporthe grisea is a haploid filamentous ascomycete and the causal agent of rice blast disease. Strains isolated from Digitaria (eg. crabgrass and finger-grass) have been defined as M. grisea while isolates from rice and other hosts were named M. oryzae. These two groups have been separted based on clear genetic differences and lack of interbreeding. Rice blast disease is a major threat worldwide, destroying enough rice annually to feed more than 60 million people. Although resistant strains of rice have been developed, M. oryzae can rapidly evolve to overcome host resistance. M. oryzae is an ideal model organism for studying plant pathogenic fungi and host-parasite interactions for several reasons: it has a relatively small genome, making it amenable to whole genome analysis; extensive genetic mapping data is available; it is closely related to the widely studied non-pathogen Neurospora crassa, enabling comparative genomic studies; a draft sequence of the host (rice) genome has been completed; it can be cultured on defined media and has a well-established transformation system, facilitating biochemical and molecular analyses; and the early stages of its infection process can be experimentally studied. A full understanding of the molecular basis of fungal phytopathogenicity and host-parasite interactions will be instrumental for the development of novel environmentally sound strategies to protect world food supplies.

The Magnaporthe oryzae genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Neurospora crassa OR74A.
datasetPresenter.description:
Neurospora crassa is a haploid, heterothallic ascomycete and analysis of genetic recombination is facilitated by the ordered arrangement of the products of meiosis in the ascospores. N. crassa perceives light only in the blue/UV range and shows a pronounced circadian rhythm which makes it a preferred model organism for investigating light perception. It is also known for studies investigating epigenetics, gene silencing, cell polarity and cell fusion.

The N. crassa genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types. Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.

datasetPresenter.name: ndisFGSC8579_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Neurospora discreta FGSC 8579.
datasetPresenter.description:
Neurospora discreta is distributed throughout western North America, Europe and Central Africa and is easily found after forest fires; it is becoming a premier model for fungal population studies, it has many of the genes important to plant pathogenesis, and Neurospora has been used as a model for the study of lignin decay by fungi.

The current draft release was submitted by John Taylor et al. from University of California, Berkeley. The gene models are predicted and functionally annotated using the JGI annotation pipeline.

datasetPresenter.name: ntetFGSC2508_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Neurospora tetrasperma FGSC 2508.
datasetPresenter.description:
Neurospora tetrasperma is an emerging model species for studying the evolution of sex chromosomes. Following meiosis, Neurospora tetrasperma produce four binucleate ascospores per ascus and have haploid nuclei of both mating-types in each ascospore. Each ascospore then give rise to a heterokaryotic and self-fertile individual (pseudohomothallism). Like its close relative, N. crassa there is evidence of repeat induced point (RIP) mutations in the N. tetrasperma genome. RIP cause C:G to T:A mutations in tandem duplications greater than ~400bp or unlinked duplicates ~1kb during the sexual cycle.

Neurospora tetrasperma was sequenced and annotated at the JGI and the project has been submitted to Genbank.

datasetPresenter.name: paphDAOMBR444_primary_genome_RSRC
