datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium aphanidermatum DAOM BR444.
datasetPresenter.description: Pythium aphanidermatum is a cosmopolitan pathogen causing damping off, root and stem rots, and blights of grasses and fruits. It has a very wide host range and causes losses on many economically important crops like beets, pepper, and cotton. The pathogen grows well in warm temperatures, making it an issue in most greenhouses. It infects preferably juvenile tissues like seedling stems. Its hyphae are reported to release a variety of elicitor-active molecules, which are carbohydrates as well as proteins. These Pythium aphanidermatum-derived elicitors are secreted and can induce programmed cell death. Pythium aphanidermatum was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: parrATCC12531_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium arrhenomanes ATCC 12531.
datasetPresenter.description: Pythium arrhenomanes is the causal agent of root rot on many Poaceae crops. It is an important seedling rice pathogen in many countries where it can reduce root growth and plant development even at warmer soil temperatures. Pythium species cause a browning, or Pythium root rot diseases in wheat and many other cereal crops. Pythium arrhenomanes produces a toxic metabolite(s), which caused root browning, stunting and inhibition of root hair formation in wheat. Pythium arrhenomanes was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: pblaNRRL1555_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phycomyces blakesleeanus NRRL 1555(-).
datasetPresenter.description:
The zygomycete fungus Phycomyces blakesleeanus has been investigated for the variety and sensitivity of its responses to light, particularly the phototropism of its giant fruiting bodies, the sporangiophores. Other light responses investigated in detail are the regulation of sporangiophore development and the regulation of the biosynthesis of the pigment beta-carotene. In addition, the Phycomyces sporangiophore reacts to a variety of environmental stimuli, including gravity, touch, wind, and the presence of nearby objects by changing the speed and direction of growth.

Annotation v2 (1 March 2010) is a consensus gene set predicted by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based, protein-based, and ab initio gene modelers, as well as Annotation v1 genes mapped to the v2 scaffolds. After filtering for homology and expression support, a total of 16528 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.

datasetPresenter.name: pcapLT1534_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora capsici LT1534.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phytophthora capsici is an oomycete plant pathogen that infects cucumber, squash, melons, pumpkin, pepper, tomato and eggplant and has recently been described on snap and lima beans. In the US, the incidence and severity of epidemics has increased dramatically. Once P. capsici is introduced into an agricultural area dormant inoculum in the form of thick-walled sexual oospores can remain viable for many years. Crop rotation and chemical applications often do not provide adequate control and losses can reach 100%. For many US vegetable producers P. capsici is the most important limiting factor.

Annotation v11 (20 August 2010) of the v11.0 assembly was produced by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based, protein-based, and ab initio gene predictors. After filtering for EST and protein homology support, a total of 19805 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.

datasetPresenter.name: pchrRP-78_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phanerochaete chrysosporium RP-78.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phanerochaete chrysosporium has been the most intensively studied white rot fungus. White rot fungi secrete an array of peroxidases and oxidases that act non-specifically via the generation of lignin free radicals, which then undergo spontaneous cleavage reactions. The non-specific nature and exceptional oxidation potential of the enzymes has attracted considerable interest for application in bioprocesses such as organopollutant degradation and fiber bleaching.

This draft was generated using a whole genome shotgun method. Genomic DNA was used to create six main libraries; four small insert (2 - 4 kb) pUC18 libraries, one medium insert (6 - 8 kb) pMCL200 library, and one large insert (35 - 40 kb) pCC1Fos library. A total of 611,025 end sequences were used in the assembly, corresponding to approximately 10.6X sequence depth. The current draft release, version 2.0, includes a total of 10,048 gene models (BestModels v2.1). Genes have been predicted and functionally annotated using the JGI annotation pipeline.

datasetPresenter.name: pcinCBS144-22_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora cinnamomi var. cinnamomi CBS 144.22.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phytophthora cinnamomi is a soil-borne water mould that produces an infection which causes a condition in plants called "root rot" or "dieback". The plant pathogen is one of the world's most invasive species and is present in over 70 countries around the world.

The Phytophthora cinnamomi var. cinnamomi genome was sequenced using the Illumina platform, 454 platform and Sanger sequencing. Each fastq file was QC filtered for artifact/process contamination and subsequently assembled with AllPathsLG release version R41043.

datasetPresenter.name: pgraCRL75-36-700-3_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici CRL 75-36-700-3.
datasetPresenter.description:
The pathogenic fungus Puccinia graminis causes stem rust in small cereal crops such as wheat, oat, rye, and barley. Stem rust, also referred to as black rust or black stem rust, is among the most destructive diseases of cereal crops and has resulted in enormous economic and yield losses. P. graminis has a complex life cycle that includes five spore stages and two very different hosts, namely, a grass for the primary host and, most commonly, barberry as the alternate host. Puccinia graminis has a number of "special forms", or forma speciales (f. sp.), which differ in their primary host specificities.

The Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici strain CRL 75-36-700-3 genome sequence submitted to INSD by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: pinfT30-4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora infestans T30-4.
datasetPresenter.description:
The oomycete Phytophthora infestans is a plant pathogen. It is the causal agent of potato blight and was responsible for the Irish Potato Famine in the 1840s.

Phytophthora infestans genome sequences annotated at the Broad Institute. Please cite Haas and kamoun et al. Nature 461, 393-398.

datasetPresenter.name: pirrDAOMBR486_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium irregulare DAOM BR486.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pythium irregulare is highly pathogenic to a wide range of cereal and legume hosts, causing significant loss in yield and vigor. It causes pre-emergent blight and post-emergent stunting of crops leading to reduction in grain production in different parts of the world. It is found in broad eco-geographic range and exhibits considerable pathogenic variation. Pythium irregulare is adapted to diverse cropping patterns in cooler, wetter temperate climates and is highly persistent in nature.

Pythium irregulare was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: piwaDAOMBR242034_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium iwayamai DAOM BR242034.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pythium iwayamai have been isolated mainly from monocotyledon plants. It grows well at lower temperatures and is pathogenic on monocot grasses under snow cover. Pythium iwayamai causes snow-rot disease of cereal plants including wheat and barley.

Pythium iwayamai was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: pjirSE8_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pneumocystis jirovecii SE8.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pneumocystis jirovecii, also known as Pneumocystis carinii f. sp. hominis, causes pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in immunocompromised people, particularly HIV/AIDS patients.

The Pneumocystis jirovecii reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: pparINRA-310_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora parasitica INRA-310.
datasetPresenter.description:
The oomycete Phytophthora parasitica is a very broad host range pathogen that causes destructive diseases of a wide variety of crop plants including tomato, pepper, eggplant, potato, tobacco, cacao, pineapple, passionfruit, safflower, sesame, common bean, banana, citrus, walnut, almond, pistachio, papaya, peach, plum, apricot, apple, macadamia, pear, avocado, guava, pomegranate, a wide variety of nursery and ornamental plants, and forest ecosystems. Some isolates are also effective pathogens of Arabidopsis thaliana and Medicago truncatula.

The Broad Institute produced a whole genome shotgun assembly from data generated by Illumina sequencing technology. It was annotated using automated methods.

datasetPresenter.name: pramPr-102_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora ramorum Pr-102.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phytophthora ramorum are stramenopiles, a major eukaryotic group that includes diatoms and brown algae and are distinct from plants, fungi, and animals. Phytophthora are common plant pathogens that infect a number of economically and agriculturally important dicot plants including crops, trees, and shrubs. Phytophthora ramorum, the particularly virulent cause of Sudden Oak Death, is destroying coastal oaks in California and the Sierra Nevada.

The draft genome sequence of P. ramorum was assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI.

datasetPresenter.name: psojP6497_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Phytophthora sojae P6497.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phytophthora sojae are stramenopiles, a major eukaryotic group that includes diatoms and brown algae and are distinct from plants, fungi, and animals. Phytophthora are common plant pathogens that infect a number of economically and agriculturally important dicot plants including crops, trees, and shrubs. P. sojai, a soybean pathogen that causes stem and root rot, is a model species for the genus since genetic and genomic resources already exist.

The draft genome sequence of Phytophthora sojae was assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI.

datasetPresenter.name: pultBR650_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium ultimum var. sporangiiferum BR650.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pythium ultimum var. sporangiiferum is one of the three Pythium ultimum species complex with distinct morphological types. Pythium ultimum var. ultimum produces oospores but very rarely sporangia and zoospores only at cool temperatures while Pythium ultimum var. sporangiiferum produces oospores readily and also produces sporangia at room temperature. Pythium ultimum var. sporangiiferum has narrower host range and is not as pathogenic as Pythium ultimum var. ultimum.

Pythium ultimatum was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: pultDAOMBR144_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium ultimum DAOM BR144.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pythium ultimum causes damping-off and root rot on a wide variety of plants. It shows worldwide distribution and has a wide range of hosts including many economically important crops. It is common in most soils of agronomic crops and forests, with distribution regulated by high soil moisture and soil temperature. Moderate infection by Pythium ultimum cause plants wilt, reduces plant populations, and retards maturation while severe infections often lead to plants collapse and death. Pythium ultimum survives as resistant resting structures in the soil and in root residues and infects the seeds and/or root tips of plants when conditions are favorable. The spread of Pythium ultimum to other susceptible plants is facilitated by mycelial growth and the movement of zoospores.

Pythium ultimatum was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: pvexDAOMBR484_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Pythium vexans DAOM BR484.
datasetPresenter.description:
Pythium vexans is one of Pythium species with oogonial ornamentation. It causes canker, damping-off and rot disease in many economically important crops including rubber trees, potato and sugar cane. Pythium vexans shows high intraspecific variation is reported to be the closest relative of Phytophthora pathogens.

Pythium vexans was sequenced and annotated at Michigan State University as part of the Pythium ultimum sequencing project.

datasetPresenter.name: rdelRA99-880_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Rhizopus delemar RA 99-880.
datasetPresenter.description:
Rhizopus oryzae is a widely dispersed fungus that can cause fatal infections in people with suppressed immune systems, especially diabetics or organ transplant recipients. Antibiotic therapy alone is rarely curative, particularly in patients with disseminated infection.

The Rhizopus oryzae sequence was produced by the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT. The genome sequence was assembled from 454 Whole Genome Shotgun methods using fragment and paired-end reads to iteratively build the supercontigs. The annotation was performed using automated methods.

datasetPresenter.name: scerS288c_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288c.
datasetPresenter.description:
The budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is one of the major model organisms for understanding cellular and molecular processes in eukaryotes. This single-celled organism is also important in industry, where it is used to make bread, beer, wine, enzymes, and pharmaceuticals.

The Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome was obtained through the Saccharomyces Genome Database.

datasetPresenter.name: sdicVS20_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Saprolegnia diclina VS20.
datasetPresenter.description:
The oomycete Saprolegnia parasitica and related pathogens are water molds in the class of Saprolegniomycetidae that attack a wide variety of fish, amphibians and crustaceans important to aquaculture and to aquatic ecosystems.

This 25x assembly was provided by the Broad Institute. It was produced from data generated by Roche/454 (fragment and 3kb paired-end libraries) and Sanger (Fosmid library) sequencing technologies.

datasetPresenter.name: sjapyFS275_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Schizosaccharomyces japonicus yFS275.
datasetPresenter.description:
A dimorphic fission yeast, capable of alternating between unicellular yeast form and multicellular true mycelium. Within the fission yeast clade, S. japonicus is an early diverging species and compared to S. pombe all 1:1 orthologs have an average amino acid identity of 55%. This fungus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus.

Sequencing data was produced by the Broad Institute. The genome is organized in 3 chromosomes with a genome size estimated at ~11.5 Mb.

datasetPresenter.name: smack-hell_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Sordaria macrospora k-hell.
datasetPresenter.description:
Sordaria macrospora is a homothallic ascomycete that is used as a model organism for studying the stages of meiosis, recombination and chromosome behavior. The fungus produce an abundance of fruiting bodies and ascospores. The ascospores are arranged in a linear order which allows for easy detection of pre- or post-segregation of allelic pairs. Ascospore-color mutations are used to recognize recombination events.

Draft sequence of the Sordaria macrospora genome was prepared and submitted to GenBank by Minou Nowrousian, Jason Stajich et al.

datasetPresenter.name: soctyFS286_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Schizosaccharomyces octosporus yFS286.
datasetPresenter.description:
Schizosaccharomyces octosporus is a fission yeast most closely related to S. cryophilus and both sister to S. pombe with S. japonicus more distant and sister to all three species. The 1:1 orthologs of S. octosporus and S. cryophilus share 85% identity on average, similar to humans and dogs. This fission yeast's genome contains no transposons, but contains sequences related to reverse transcriptase and integrase that may represent extinct transposons. Telomere repeats (GGGTTACTT) matched a one-and-a-half repeat unit sequence at the putative telomerase-RNA locus, similar to the configuration in S. pombe (GGTTAC). There is no similarity between centromeric repeats in S. pombe and S. octosporus but karyotype (3 chromosomes) and pericentrometric gene order are conserved. The earlier diverging fission yeast S. japonicus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus. The retention of repetative elements in the centromeres of S. octosporus, S. cryophilus and S. pombe, despite having lost transposons, implies an important function for centromeric repeats.

Sequencing data was produced by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: sparCBS223-65_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Saprolegnia parasitica CBS 223.65.
datasetPresenter.description:
The oomycete Saprolegnia parasitica and related pathogens are water molds in the class of Saprolegniomycetidae that attack a wide variety of fish, amphibians and crustaceans important to aquaculture and to aquatic ecosystems. They cause Saprolegniosis, a disease that is characterized by visible white or grey patches of filamentous mycelium on the body or fins of freshwater fish. Saprolegnia parasitica is economically one of the most important fish pathogens, especially on catfish, salmon and trout species. It causes millions of dollar losses to the aquaculture industry worldwide and has also been linked to declining wild fish stocks and amphibian populations around the world.

The Broad Institute produced a whole genome shotgun assembly from data generated by Roche/454 (fragment and 3kb paired-end libraries) and Sanger (Fosmid library) sequencing technologies. The resulting 25x assembly was made public in December of 2009.

datasetPresenter.name: spom972h_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Schizosaccharomyces pombe 972h-.
datasetPresenter.description:
The fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe is an excellent model organism for studying eukaryotic processes such as cell cycle control, mitosis and meiosis, DNA repair and recombination, splicing, and the checkpoint controls important for genome stability. Schizosaccharomyces pombe forms a rod-shaped cell that grows at its tips and divides by medial fission. Although originally isolated in East African millet beer ('pombe' means 'beer' in Swahili), Schizosaccharomyces pombe is not recommended for brewing.

Sequencing data was obtained from Pombase, European Bioinformatics Institute(EBI).

datasetPresenter.name: spunDAOMBR117_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Spizellomyces punctatus DAOM BR117.
datasetPresenter.description:
S. punctatus is the type species of the fungal genus Spizellomyces, which is in the phylum Chytridiomycota (chytrids). Like all chytrids, Spizellomyces produces uniflagellated zoospores during its reproductive cycle, but in contrast to other zoosporic fungi (e.g. Allomyces), spizellomycetalean zoospores can be amoeboid while actively swimming, and the flagellar insertion site may move to a lateral position.

Sequencing data provided by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: sreiSRZ2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Sporisorium reilianum SRZ2.
datasetPresenter.description:
Sporisorium reilianum is a biotrophic pathogen of maize and closely related to Ustilago maydis. The genomes of both fungi are highly syntenic but these two pathogens cause different symptoms on maize. U. maydis infection leads to formation of spore-filled tumors in the vicinity of the site of infection (on leaves, stems or flowers) whereas S. reilianum infect seedling plants and spread throughout the plant without noticeable impact on plant health until flowering when spore-filled sori appear in the inflorescences.

Library construction and genome sequencing of S. reilianum strain SRZ2 was done at 454 Life Sciences (USA). As a first step a whole genome shotgun random library was constructed and sequenced using the Genome Sequencer 20 (Roche). In a second step, the genome was sequenced from a newly generated paired-end library of S. reilianum strain SRZ2 using the Genome Sequencer FLX (Roche). In a third step, the scaffold-assembly was verified by generating an NheI-based Optical Map (OpGen). Optical Mapping resulted in the assembly of 23 chromosomes on which 99.75% of the genome assembly could be placed. The total genome size based on Optical Mapping is estimated to be 18.7 Mb. Thus, the assembly contains 97 % of total sequence information.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added

datasetPresenter.name: sscl1980UF-70_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Sclerotinia sclerotiorum 1980 UF-70.
datasetPresenter.description:
Sclerotinia sclerotiorum (Lib.) de Bary is among the world's most successful and omnivorous fungal plant pathogens, with a host range of greater than 400 plant species. Despite decades of dedicated effort, resistant germplasm is still lacking in economically important crops. As an exemplar of soilborne pathogens and necrotrophic pathogenesis, S. sclerotiorum is a model for development of asexual, persistant propagules, somatic compatibility, and sexual sporulation. It is also central to a group of Ascomycetes with poorly known evolutionary relationships.

The Sclerotinia sclerotiorum reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Sclerotinia sclerotiorum strain 1980 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: tmarATCC18224_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Talaromyces marneffei ATCC 18224.
datasetPresenter.description:
Talaromyces marneffei is a thermally dimorphic opportunistic fungal pathogen and thus can grow as an intracellular macrophage-associated fission yeast at 37 degree C, causing penicilliosis. This unique feature makes it the only pathogenic species of Talaromyces within this taxon of more than 270 species. The infection is endemic in Southeast Asia and associated with immunocompromised individuals. It infects up to 10% of AIDS patients in this region and often result into a fatal systemic mycosis. The fungus is believed to be haploid, with at least seven chromosomes.

The Talaromyces marneffei reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Talaromyces marneffei strain ATCC 18224 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the J. Craig Ventor Institute.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: tmesDSM1558_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Tremella mesenterica DSM 1558.
datasetPresenter.description:
Tremella species are jelly fungi found commonly associated with dead and decaying wood. Jelly fungi are heterobasidiomycetes and named according to their fruiting body structures, the consistency of which is similar to jelly. Of the Tremella sp., Tremella mesenterica has garnered the most attention: the key interest in T. mesenterica is the potential to derive fuel ethanol from lignocellulosic biomass. Identifying the factors responsible for degrading biomass is central to understanding the biological processes that impact bio-energy research. The biodegradation of wood components occurs in the presence of mostly wood rotting basidiomycetous fungi. T. mesenterica degrades lignin on decaying wood causing white rot disease, leaving the wood bleached or white in color. Lignin is an integral part of the plant cell wall and one of the most abundant biomolecules in the world next to cellulose. Lignin degradation also requires the presence of cellulose. The process occurs in two steps, saccharification and fermentation, which results in the production of fuel ethanol.

Draft assembly release version 1.0 of whole-genome shotgun reads was constructed at JGI with Arachne, using paired end sequencing reads at an average coverage of 7.44X. The draft annotation release version 1.0 of the v1.0 assembly was produced by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA/EST-based, homology-based, and ab initio gene predictors. After filtering for EST and homology support, a total of 8313 genes were structurally and functionally annotated. 77% of the genes have homology support, 52% have Pfam support, and 31% have EST support.

datasetPresenter.name: treeQM6a_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Trichoderma reesei QM6a.
datasetPresenter.description:
Trichoderma reesei is an industrially important cellulolytic filamentous fungus. In light of of T. reesei's capacity to secrete large amounts of cellulases and hemi cellulases, the DOE is funding research into developing T. reesei as a host to produce low cost enzymes for the conversion of plant biomass materials into industrially useful bioproducts such as sugars and bioethanol.

The Department of Energy (DOE) Joint Genome Institute sequenced the Trichoderma reesei strain QM6a genome using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The draft assembly currently consists of 170 scaffolds. The Trichoderma reesei genome is being finished at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

datasetPresenter.name: tstiATCC10500_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500.
datasetPresenter.description:
Talaromyces stipitatus is a non-pathogenic filamentous fungus that is the closest known relative of the pathogenic fungus Penicillium marneffei. Talaromyces stipitatus is saprophytic and is commonly found in soil, dung, and decaying plant material. It secretes several feruloyl esterases, which hydrolyze the ester bond between the hydroxycinnamic acids and sugars present in plant cell walls. These enzymes have several potential applications in the agri-food industries.

The Talaromyces stipitatus reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the J. Craig Venter Institute.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed

datasetPresenter.name: umay521_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Ustilago maydis 521.
datasetPresenter.description:
Ustilago maydis is a ubiquitous pathogen of maize and a well-established model organism for the study of plant-microbe interactions. This basidiomycete fungus does not use aggressive virulence strategies to kill its host. U. maydis belongs to the group of biotrophic parasites (the smuts) that depend on living tissue for proliferation and development.

U. maydis strain 521 (a1 b1) was sequenced by two independent strategies, a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach and a map-based sequencing strategy. The Ustilago maydis sequence project is part of the Broad Institute's Fungal Genome Initiative and was accomplished through collaborations with the Broad Institute, Bayer CropScience AG and Exelixis, Inc.

Bayer CropScience contributed their low-coverage genome sequence of U. maydis strain 521. These data consist of 17.4 Mb in 28 contigs and were generated from a minimal tiling path of overlapping BAC clones that cover 23 chromosomes. Exelixis has provided 5X whole-genome shotgun sequences of U. maydis strain FB1 that is assembled and aligned against the WGS assembly of strain 521 to identify polymorphism between these two strains.

datasetPresenter.name: ylipCLIB122_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Yarrowia lipolytica CLIB122.
datasetPresenter.description:
Yarrowia lipolytica is a nonpathogenic yeast that can use hydrocarbons and various fats as carbon sources. It is often isolated from foods, such as cheese and sausage, or from natural environments, such as oil fields. Yarrowia lipolytica is very distantly related to other yeasts; instead, it shares several properties with filamentous fungi, including differentiating into a true mycelial form under certain growth conditions. Yarrowia lipolytica does not undergo mating type switching. This yeast is used as an organism in basic research, as well as for industrial applications, such as the production of citric acid and flavoring agents.

The Yarrowia lipolytica reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Yarrowia lipolytica strain CLIB122 genome sequence, assembly, and annotation submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Genolevures Consortium.

datasetPresenter.name: aoryRIB40_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus oryzae RIB40.
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus oryzae RIB40/ATCC 42149 was originally sequenced by the NITE, AIST, A. oryzae consortium. Sequence and annotation were downloaded from the Broad Institute Aspergillus download page on 23-Feb-2009. Gene models were subsequently refined at AspGD by PASA alignment of A. oryzae ESTs and RNA-Seq provided by Dr. Kazuhiro and RNA-Seq reads reported in Wang (2010)

datasetPresenter.name: cposSilveira_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Coccidioides posadasii str. Silveira
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and annotation for Coccidioides posadasii str. Silveira:
Coccidiodes posadasii str. Silveira exhibits enhanced virulence in mice and is the most widely reported experimental strain. Coccidiodes posadasii and the closely related Coccidioides immitis are ascomycete fungi found in the desert regions of North America, Mexico, and South America that cause coccidioidomycosis, or valley fever. These two fungi are responsible for nearly all cases of Valley Fever in the United States.

The Coccidioides posadasii str. Silveira genome was sequenced at the Broad Institute to 5X coverage from genomic DNA provided by John Galgiani.

The Coccidioides immitis sequence project targeted multiple Coccidioides strains and was supported by both NHGRI and NIAID through the Broad Institute's Fungal Genome Initiative and its Microbial Sequencing Center (MSC).

link.text: Coccidiodes Sequencing Project at the Broad Institute

datasetPresenter.name: cimmRMSCC2394_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence for Coccidioides immitis RMSCC 2394
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence for Coccidioides immitis RMSCC 2394:
Coccidioides immitis is a soil fungus which causes coccidioidomycosis, also known as "valley fever," a serious and sometimes fatal disease in otherwise healthy people. C. immitis was placed on a NIAID group II list of priority emerging and re-emerging pathogens. Coccidioides species have also become models for studying the evolutionary biology of pathogenic fungi.

The Coccidioides immitis RMSCC 2394 genome was sequenced at the Broad Institute to 8X coverage from genomic DNA provided by John Galgiani.

The Coccidioides immitis sequence project targeted multiple Coccidioides strains and was supported by both NHGRI and NIAID through the Broad Institute's Fungal Genome Initiative and its Microbial Sequencing Center (MSC).

datasetPresenter.name: cdeuR265_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptococcus deuterogattii R265.
datasetPresenter.description:
C. deuterogattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.

The Cryptococcus deuterogattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, data source changed, organism name changed from Cryptococcus gattii R265

datasetPresenter.name: afisNRRL181_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Aspergillus fischeri NRRL 181.
datasetPresenter.description:
Aspergillus fischeri, the closest relative of the major pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus, can cause keratitis and pulmonary aspergillosis in transplant patients. It is a sexual Aspergillus species. This filamentous fungus is found in soil, and its spores are found in agricultural products.

The Aspergillus fischeri reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is based on the genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by TIGR.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, data source changed, organism name changed from Neosartorya fischeri NRRL 181

datasetPresenter.name: bcinB05-10_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Botrytis cinerea B05.10.
datasetPresenter.description: This pathogen causes serious losses in more than 200 crop species worldwide. Although there are fungicides for its control, many classes of fungicides have failed due to its genetic plasticity. It has become an important model for molecular study of necrotrophic fungi. The aim of the genome sequencing is to provide the community with the tools to analyse and dissect the genetic basis of pathogenicity.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Botrytis cinerea Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, data source changed, organism name changed from Botryotinia fuckeliana B05.10

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_B_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Candida albicans SC5314_B.
datasetPresenter.description:
Candida albicans, a diploid sexual fungus, is the causal agent of opportunistic infections in humans, the most common being oral and vaginal infections. Systemic fungal infections have emerged as important causes of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, organ or bone marrow transplantation). In addition, hospital-related infections in patients not previously considered at risk (e.g., patients on an intensive care unit) have become a cause of major health concern.

The C. albicans SC5314_B genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly was done by the Stanford Genome Technology Center and the Biotechnology Research Institute of the National Research Council of Canada. It was obtained from the Candida Genome Database (CGD.org).

Contact CGD at candida-curator@lists.stanford.edu

datasetPresenter.name: hcapG186AR_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Histoplasma capsulatum G186AR.
datasetPresenter.description:
Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).

The Latin American Histoplasma capsulatum class H81 strain G186AR was assembled from sequence reads produced by both the Broad Institute and the Washington University School of Medicine. Sequences were obtained from 454 pOT library beads and fosmid libraries containing 3.1kb, 4.1kb, 5.7 kb, and 39kb inserts. The resulting 10X assembly was made public in May 2008.
datasetPresenter.acknowledgement: Histoplasma capsulatum Sequencing Project, Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, sequence-changed, mitochondrial genome and annotation added, data source changed, organism name changed from Ajellomyces capsulatus G186AR

datasetPresenter.name: hcapNAm1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Histoplasma capsulatum NAm1.
datasetPresenter.description:
Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).

For Histoplasma capsulatum class NAmI strain WU24, the Broad Institute produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in September 2005, and the results of automated genome annotation was made public May, 2006.

datasetPresenter.name: scerS288c_interaction_SGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Yeast two-hybrid interaction data.
datasetPresenter.description: SGD's interaction data encompasses protein-protein and protein-RNA interactions, as recorded by the Biological General Repository for Interaction Database. BioGRID is a repository of interaction data manually curated from scientific literature for Saccharomyces cerevisiae as well as other organisms. BioGRID interactions are binary relationships between two proteins or genes. Interactions include physical and genetic interactions. Physical interactions are defined as the direct physical binding of two proteins, or co-existence in a stable complex, whereas genetic interactions are interactions between two or more mutants.

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_Desai_GlycerolRole_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Regulatory role of glycerol in Candida albicans biofilm formation
datasetPresenter.description: Biofilm formation on medically implanted devices by Candida albicans poses a significant clinical challenge. Here we compared biofilm-associated gene expression in two clinical C. albicans isolates, SC5314 and WO-1, to identify shared gene regulatory responses that may be functionally relevant. Among the 50 genes most highly expressed in biofilms relative to planktonic (suspension-grown) cells, we were able to recover insertion mutations in 25 genes. We observed that 20 of the 25 mutants have altered biofilm-related properties, including cell-substrate adherence, cell-cell signaling, and azole susceptibility. We focused on the most highly up-regulated gene in biofilms, RHR2, which specifies the glycerol biosynthetic enzyme glycerol-3-phosphate phosphatase. Glycerol is 5-fold more abundant in biofilm cells than planktonic cells, and an rhr2D/D strain accumulates 2-fold less biofilm glycerol than the wild type. Under in vitro growth conditions, the rhr2D/D mutant has reduced biofilm biomass and reduced adherence to silicone. The rhr2D/D mutant is severely defective in biofilm formation in vivo, in a rat catheter infection model. Expression profiling of the rhr2D/D mutant indicates that it has reduced expression of cell surface adhesin genes ALS1, ALS3, and HWP1, as well as a large fraction of all other biofilm up-regulated genes. Reduced adhesin expression is the cause of the rhr2D/D mutant biofilm defect, because overexpression of ALS1, ALS3, or HWP1 restores biofilm formation ability to the mutant in vitro and in vivo. Our findings indicate that internal glycerol has a regulatory role in biofilm gene expression, and that adhesin genes are among the main functional Rhr2-regulated genes.

templateInjector.prop: Gene expression profiles, in duplicate; (1) for biofilm vs. planktonic growth conditions for the two wild-type clinical isolates of Candida albicans (SC5314 and WO1-white/WO1-opaque), and (2) for rhr2Î/Î mutant and complemented strain.

Three biological replicates of both genotypes in each morphological phases were analyzed.

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_Lemoine_DrugResistance_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Drug susceptible clinical isolates of Candida albicans frequently become highly tolerant to drugs during chemotherapy, with dreadful consequences on patient health. We used RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) to analyze the transcriptomes of a CDR (Candida Drug Resistance) strain and its isogenic drug sensitive counterpart. Gu4 is a fluconazole susceptible clinical isolate obtained from an early infection episode. Gu5 is the corresponding fluconazole resistant clinical isolate obtained from later episode in the same patient treated with fluconazole. RNA-seq unveiled differential expression of 228 genes including a) genes previously identified as involved in CDR, b) genes not previously associated to the CDR phenotype, and c) novel transcripts whose function as a gene is uncharacterized. In particular, we show for the first time that CDR acquisition is correlated with an overexpression of the transcription factor encoding gene CZF1. CZF1 null mutants were sensitive to many drugs, independently of known multidrug resistance mechanisms. We show that CZF1 acts as a repressor of Î²-glucan synthesis, thus negatively regulating cell wall integrity. Finally, our RNA-seq data allowed us to identify a new transcribed region, upstream of the TAC1 gene, which encodes the major CDR transcriptional regulator. Our results open new perspectives to the role of Czf1 and to our understanding of the transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms that lead to the acquisition of drug resistance in C. albicans, with potential future improvements of therapeutic strategies.

templateInjector.prop: RNA sequencing was performed on 2 Candida albicans strains (Gu4 fluconazole susceptible and Gu5 fluconazole resistant). For each strain, we sequenced 2 biological replicates.

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_Snyder_ComprehensiveAnnotation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Candida albicans data from Michael Snyder et al. from Synder Lab at Stanford University on Comprehensive Annotation of the transcriptome of the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans using RNA-Seq. Massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of cDNA was used to generate a high-resolution map of the C. albicans transcriptome under several different environmental conditions. The regions that are transcribed under the different conditions have been quantitatively determined and 635 novel transcriptionally active regions (TARs) and numerous novel introns have been identified.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Data was genereated from C. albicans grown under a total of nine different in vitro conditions which included hyphae-inducing conditions, tissue culture medium, high and low oxidative stress, nitrosative stress and cell wall damage inducing conditions. Using our data set of about 177 million mapped reads, we have significantly refined the primary annotations of the C. albicans genome by determining the position of transcripts in the genomes, including 602 newly identified transcripts for strain SC5314, and by identifying 41 new introns.

templateInjector.prop: Conditions profiled: cell-wall-damaging environment, high oxidative stress, low oxidative stress, media containing serum, medium at pH4, medium at pH8, nitrosative stress, non-cell-wall-damaging environment, non-nitrosative environment, no oxidative stress, YPD, YPD media, YPD media containing serum

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_Kim_AzoleDrugs_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fluconazole Sensitivity of Wild-type vs cfo1 Mutant
datasetPresenter.description: Transcriptome profiling of wild type and cfo1 mutant with fluconazole treatment in Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99. Purpose: The goals of this study are to compare cfo1 mutant transcriptome profiling (RNA-seq) to wild-type with or without fluconazole treatment in Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99. Methods: mRNA profiles of wild-type and cfo1 mutant with or without fluconazole treatment were generated by RNA-Seq, using Illumina GAIIx. The sequence reads that passed quality filters were mapped to reference genome and the normalized RPKM values were calculated by CLC Genomics Workbench. Results: Compared to wild-type, a number of genes were differentially expressed in the cfo1 mutant, especially genes involved in iron homeostasis and transport, ergosterol biosynthesis, mitochondrial function and respiration. Conclusions: Our data suggested reduced expression of the genes in the respiratory chain is the main reason for altered antifungal sensitivity of the cfo1 mutant. The results of our study revealed that iron uptake plays a key role in fluconazole sensitivity of C. neoformans.

templateInjector.prop: mRNA profiles of wild-type and cfo1 mutant with fluconazole treatment were generated by RNA-Seq, using Illumina GAIIx.

datasetPresenter.description: Purpose: To examine the comparative transcriptional profiles of WT and rim101 mutant cells in host-mimicking in vitro conditions to determine genes that are responsible for the increased virulence of the rim101 strain. The rim101 mutant is able to trigger an overactive inflammatory response, presumably by exposing an antigenic trigger. Using transcriptional profiling, we determined that many genes involved in cell wall processes were differentially transcribed between the wild type and the mutant strain.

templateInjector.prop: Whole mRNA profiles of WT and rim101 cells were generated by deep sequencing using Illumina GAII.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Glass_CellulaseSecretion_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Inducer Free Cellulase Secretion in Neurospora Crassa.
datasetPresenter.description: Purpose: To explore conservation of gene regulation by the transcription factor clr-2/clrB in Neurospora crassa and Aspergillus nidulans Methods: mRNA from wild type and clr-2/clrB mutants were collected after a culture shift from sucrose/glucose to Avicel (crystaline cellulose) or no carbon media Results: We show that N. crassa and A. nidulans have similair global transcriptional responses to Avicel, with several hundred genes showing specific induction, though the induced genes are more specifically targeted at cellulose for N. crassa and more targeted at hemicellulose and pectin for A. nidulans. clr-2/clrB has a conserved fundamental function in cellulose induction, though the mechanism has diverged. Misexpression of clr-2 is sufficeint for inducer free cellulase secretion in N. crassa, but neither clrB or heterologous clr-2 is sufficient for inducer free cellulase secretion in A. nidulans. Conclusions: Our study demonstrates a conserved and essential role in cellulose utilization for the transcription factor clr-2 in filamentous ascomycetes and demonstrates that manipulation of clr-2 expression can be used to control cellulase expression in some species.

templateInjector.prop: Biological triplicates of liquid culture N. crassa and A. nidulans were harvested at 4 hours and 6 hours, respectively, after a switch to media of interest. Global mRNA abundances from liquid cultures of N. crassa and A. nidulans were measured by sequencing on the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx and HiSeq2000 platforms.

The solution structure of the C-terminal domain of Schizosaccharomyces pombe Dicer (Dcr1) is reported here. The C-terminal domain of S pombe Dicer (Dcr1) structure reveals an unusual double-stranded RNA binding domain (dsRBD) fold embedding a novel zinc-binding motif that is conserved among dicers in yeast and constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases.

datasetPresenter.name: cposSilveira_Narra_WT_CBS1mutant_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome profiling of Coccidioides posadasii WT and CPS1 deletion mutant
datasetPresenter.summary: Although the role of CPS1 in virulence is not understood, phenotypic alterations and transcription differences between WT and CPS1 deletion mutant were observed. In this study RNA-Seq experiment comparing WT and Δcps1 mutant was done in duplicates. Considering its apparently complete attenuation of virulence and the high degree of resistance to C. posadasii infection when used as a vaccine, the Δcps1 is a promising vaccine candidate for preventing coccidioidomycosis in humans or other animals.
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides species (C. immitis and C. posadasii) cause coccidioidomycosis (also known as valley fever). Inhalation of a 2 to 4um arthroconidium (spore) triggers a respiratory infection with spores growing as parasitic structures, known as spherules that can reach between 80 to 100 um in diameter. The in vitro phenotype of Δcps1 mutant showed slower growth of mycelia with delayed and lower spore production compared to WT, and in vitro spherules were smaller. For RNA-Seq analysis, strains were grown in 100 ml of modified Converse liquid medium with 3 Ã108 C. posadasii or Δcps1 strain freshly harvested spores with shaking at 180 rpm for 48 h. Spherules from C. posadasii and Δcps1 strains were prepared and resuspended in diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated H2O prior to assessment of their quality and concentration with an Agilent Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA) and with the Quant-iT RiboGreen RNA assay kit (Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY).

We use the mixed [sum] of total RNAs from this experiment as control RNA. Cy5 is used as the sample dye and Cy3 as the control dye.

datasetPresenter.name: scerS288c_microarrayExpression_Spellman_CellCycle_1998_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data.
datasetPresenter.description:
Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data.

The following experiments from Spellman et. al. are represented:
  • Pheromone synchronization time course:  The cell cycle of an asynchronous population of yeast strain DBY8724 was arrested by incubating with alpha-factor for 2 hours (MATa cells arrested in G1).  Time points for microarray analysis were collected for 140 minutes at 7-minute intervals following release from cell cycle arrest.
  • Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation):  Unbudded daughter cells of strain DBY7286 were harvested using an elutriator following sonication (achieves small G1 cells).  Cells were returned to culture and samples for microarray analysis were harvested at 30-minute intervals for 6.5 hours.
  • Cdc15-based synchronization time course:  The cell cycle of temperature sensitive cdc 15-2 (strain DBY8728) cells was arrested at 37°C for 3.5 hours (cells arrested late in mitosis). Release from cell cycle arrest was achieved by growing cells in permissive temperature (23°C), and cells were harvested at 10-minute intervals for 300 minutes.
  • Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p:  cln3 cell were arrested in late G1 due by temperature-shift inactivating Cdc43p. Clb2 experiment was performed by growing clb2 cells and arresting at M with nocodazole. These RNA were compared to the control wild-type cells arrested at G1 and M using the same approaches. Values represent the relative expression of the mutant to wild-type. cln3-1 is the 40 minute and cln3-2 is the 30 minute experiment. The clb2-1 and clb2-2 represent replicate experiments of the 40-minute time point.
Raw data from this study may be obtained from here.

The following experiment from Cho et. al. is represented:
  • Cdc28-based synchronization time course:  Cdc 28-13 temperature sensitive cells were arrested late in G1 by incubating at 37°C.  Reinitiation of the cell cycle was achieved by shifting cells to the permissive temperature (25°C).  Four microarray analysis cells were collected at 10-minute intervals for 160 minutes.

templateInjector.prop: The expression value is log2(sample/common reference)

datasetPresenter.name: anidFGSCA4_Glass_CellulaseSecretion_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Inducer-Free Cellulase Secretion in Aspergillus nidulans
datasetPresenter.summary: Global mRNA abundances from liquid cultures of A. nidulans were measured by sequencing on the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx and HiSeq2000 platforms. Cultures were harvested at 6 hours, after a switch to media of interest.
datasetPresenter.description:
Purpose:
To explore conservation of gene regulation by the transcription factor clr-2/clrB in Aspergillus nidulans

Methods:
mRNA from wild type and clr-2/clrB mutants were collected after a culture shift from sucrose/glucose to Avicel (crystaline cellulose) or no carbon media

Results:
We show that A. nidulans has global transcriptional responses to Avicel, with several hundred genes showing specific induction, though the induced genes are more specifically targeted at cellulose for A. nidulans. clr-2/clrB has a conserved fundamental function in cellulose induction, though the mechanism has diverged. Misexpression of clr-2 is sufficeint for inducer free cellulase secretion in A. nidulans

Conclusions:
Our study demonstrates a conserved and essential role in cellulose utilization for the transcription factor clr-2 in filamentous ascomycetes and demonstrates that manipulation of clr-2 expression can be used to control cellulase expression in some species.

Samples:
GSM1078926 Anidulans WT Avicel #1
GSM1078927 Anidulans WT Avicel #2
GSM1078928 Anidulans WT Avicel #3
GSM1078929 Anidulans WT No Carbon #1
GSM1078930 Anidulans WT No Carbon #2
GSM1078931 Anidulans WT No Carbon #3
GSM1078935 Anidulans clrB Avicel #1
GSM1078936 Anidulans clrB Avicel #2
GSM1078937 Anidulans clrB Avicel #3

templateInjector.prop: Biological triplicates of liquid culture A. nidulans were harvested at 6 hours, after a switch to media of interest. Global mRNA abundances from liquid cultures of N. crassa were measured by sequencing on the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx and HiSeq2000 platforms.

datasetPresenter.name: anidFGSCA4_Lind_SecondaryMetabolism_Anid_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomes of wild-type vs veA and mtfA deletion mutants
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA sequencing of A. nidulans wild-type and deletion mutants of the secondary metabolite regulators, VeA and MtfA.
datasetPresenter.description:
Secondary metabolite production is tightly controlled by a complex network of master regulators. Deletion mutants of two such regulators, VeA and MtfA, were prepared and their transcriptomes were compared to wild type. Transcriptomes of A.nidulans wild-type and veA and mtfA deletion mutants were determined by Illumina RNA sequencing.

Strains used in this study:
Wild Type: A. nidulans TRV50.2 (WT)
veA deletion: A. nidulans TXFp2.1(ΔveA)
mtfA deletion: A. nidulans TRVpΔmtfA

Note that the RNAseq analysis method used by EuPathDB resources might differ from those used by the authors in the original publication. This may cause some differences in overall results but the general trend should be the same. EuPathDB obtains RNAseq data from the sequence read archive (SRA). Reads from biological replicates are concatenated and mapped to the appropriate reference genome using the RNAseq Unified Mapper (RUM). RUM generates FPKM values, coverage plots and splice junction evidence. Fold change and percentile queries are based on the generated FPKM values.

templateInjector.prop: A.nidulans wt and veA and mtfA mutants

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_phenotype_QIAGEN_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Manually curated phenotypes for Cryptococcus species
datasetPresenter.description:
The manually curated phenotypes for Cryptococcus species in FungiDB represent the phenotype data that is provided by Diane O. Inglis from Cryptococcus RO3 Project and additional publications curated by EuPathDB curators. The phenotypes from Cryptococcus RO3 project were previously represented in controlled vocabularies in the gene pages and were only available through a text search. These phenotypes were reformatted at FungiDB in order to comply with EuPathDB's broader approach for phenotype curation. We have followed a post-compositional ("entity + quality") approach for phenotype annotation and mapped the phenotypes to multiple ontologies. The primary ontology for "quality" terms is Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO). Gene Ontology (GO), Fungal Gross Anatomy Ontology (FAO), Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) and Ascomycete Phenotype Ontology (APO) were used for "entity" terms. GO was preferred over other ontologies and was used to annotate phenotypic observations relating to biological processes and molecular functions. Similarly, FAO and ChEBI were used to annotate phenotypes relating to fungal structures and chemical compounds respectively. APO terms were still used for curation, if these phenotypic terms were missing in other ontologies and they are beyond the scope of other ontologies used (e.g. colony morphology). This dataset is also further expanded by phenotypes from additional publications that were curated at EuPathDB.

Cryptococcus RO3 Project Curators: Diane O. Inglis and Marek S. Skrzypek
Cryptococcus RO3 Project PIs: Gavin Sherlock and Jason Stajich

link.text: Original phenotypic annotations from Cryptococcus RO3 Project

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_phenotype_DATA_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Manually curated phenotypes for Aspergillus species
datasetPresenter.description: The manually curated phenotypes for Aspergillus species in FungiDB represent the phenotype data that is publicly available in the AspGD database. These phenotypes were manually curated from the literature by curatorial staff at AspGD. The phenotypes were represented in Ascomycete Phenotype Ontology (APO) in AspGD. These phenotypes from AspGD were reformatted at FungiDB in order to comply with EuPathDB's broader approach for phenotype curation. Like AspGD, we have also followed a post-compositional ("entity + quality") approach for phenotype annotation. In addition, APO-based phenotypes were converted to multiple ontologies. The primary ontology for "quality" terms is Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO). Gene Ontology (GO), Fungal Gross Anatomy Ontology (FAO), Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) and Ascomycete Phenotype Ontology (APO) were used for "entity" terms. GO was preferred over other ontologies and was used to annotate phenotypic observations relating to biological processes and molecular functions. Similarly, FAO and ChEBI were used to annotate phenotypes relating to fungal structures and chemical compounds respectively. APO terms were still used for curation, if these phenotypic terms were missing in other ontologies and they are beyond the scope of other ontologies used (e.g. colony morphology).

datasetPresenter.name: pbraPb18_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Pb18.
datasetPresenter.description: Paracoccidioides is a fungal pathogen and the cause of paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM). PCM is a clinically important fungal disease that can acquire serious systemic forms and is caused by the thermodimorphic fungal Paracoccidioides spp. PCM is endemic in Latin America with ~80% cases occurring in Brazil. A reference strain of P. brasiliensis Pb18 was sequenced by the The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. 94% of the P. brasiliensis Pb18 assembly were mapped onto five chromosomes. Pb18 genome at 9.8X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_Chen_HumanMeningitis_Single_End_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: The Cryptococcus neoformans transcriptome at the site of human meningitis (single-read data)
datasetPresenter.summary: The Cryptococcus neoformans transcriptome at the site of human meningitis
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptococcus neoformans is a major cause of fungal meningitis in immunocompromised individuals worldwide. C. neoformans, an environmental, opportunistic yeast, is annually responsible for an estimated million cases of meningitis and over 600,000 deaths, mostly among HIV-infected patients in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. Using RNA-seq, we analyzed the gene expression of two strains of C. neoformans obtained from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of infected patients. Gene expression of G0 and HC1 clinical strains were compared under three conditions (in vivo CSF, ex vivo CSF, and laboratory culture).

templateInjector.prop: 2 strains (G0 and HC1) and 2 conditions (in vivo CSF, YPD)

datasetPresenter.name: mory70-15_Islam_WheatBlast_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of Magnaporthe oryzae isolates collected from Bangladeshi fields
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of Magnaporthe oryzae isolates collected from Bangladeshi fields
datasetPresenter.description: In February 2016, a new fungal disease was spotted in wheat fields across eight districts in Bangladesh. The epidemic spread to an estimated 15,000 hectares, about 16 % of the cultivated wheat area in Bangladesh, with yield losses reaching up to 100 %. Within weeks of the onset of the epidemic, we performed transcriptome sequencing of symptomatic leaf samples collected directly from Bangladeshi fields. Sequence reads were obtained from RNA extracted from wheat leaf blades from fields infected with the wheat blast fungus. Four samples were collected from non-symptomatic and symptomatic leaf blades. 70-15 is a hybrid lab strain derived from a cross between two blast fungus isolates; 104-3 isolated from rice (Oryza spp.) and AR4 isolated from weeping lovegrass (Eragrostis curvula), with subsequent backcrosses to rice infecting isolate Guy11 (Chiapello et al., 2015). It is now established that 70-15 carries a hybrid genome given that the Eragrostis parent is not classified as M. oryzae per se (Chiapello et al., 2015). RNA-Seq reads were aligned to the reference genome M. oryzae 70-15 using GSNAP. HTSeq-counts was used to determine counts and unique alignments only were taken for generation of FPKM. Any samples with replicates are normally also analysed using DESeq2 for differential analysis.

datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus fumigatus was cultured in a chemostat for 12.5 hours, and switched to hypoxia (0.2% oxygen). Samples were collected at the beginning of the experiment, before the switch to hypoxia, and 2, 6, 12 and 24 hours after the switch. datasetPresenter.name: cposSilveira_HTS_SNP_Whole_Population_Genome_SNP_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Coccidioides whole population genome SNP analysis reveals local population structure and patterns of dispersal in the Western Hemisphere.
datasetPresenter.description: â¨Coccidioides immitis and C. posadasii are pathogenic environmental fungi causing coccidioidomycosis primarily in the desert Southwest of the United States, with scattered endemic foci throughout the Western Hemisphere. The complexities of their recombining genomes has, until recently, limited the development of tools for molecular epidemiology and phylogeographic analysis at both the regional and local levels. Here we perform whole genome sequence analyses of 64 new and 28 previously published genomes to ascertain the population structure of Coccidioides, particularly within local subpopulations of C. posadasii. The results provide evidence of substantial population structure in C. posadasii and demonstrate presence of distinct geographic clades in Central and Southern Arizona as well as dispersed populations in Texas, Mexico and South and Central America. Although a smaller number of C. immitis strains were included in the analyses, some evidence of phylogeographic structure was detected in this species as well. Specifically, newly identified clinical and environmental strains from Washington State formed â¨a distinct well-supported clade on C. immitis genomic phylogeny. Phylogenetic analyses indicated that C. posadasii is the most ancient of the two species, and Southern Arizona contains the most diverse subpopulations. A model for distribution of C. posadasii out of the Southern Arizona region is proposed.â¨

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Sachs_Light_Regulation_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: ADV-1 gene target in C. crassa ChIP-seq
datasetPresenter.summary: ADV-1 functions to generate distinct temporal dynamics of target genes in Neurospora crassa.
datasetPresenter.description: To identify genes controlled by ADV-1, ChIP-seq experiments were carried out in a strain containing C-terminal V5 epitope-tagged ADV-1 at the native locus (ADV-1::V5). The tagged protein functioned normally during development as both WT and ADV-1::V5 cells produced protoperithecia. ADV-1::V5 protein (~79 kDa) was specifically detected in western blots using anti-V5 antibody. ADV-1::V5 protein was observed in cells grown in constant dark (DD), and the levels were increased following 15, 30, and 60 min of light treatment. Therefore, ADV-1::V5 ChIP-seq using anti-V5 antibody was carried out on cells harvested after growth in the dark, and after light treatment for 15, 30, and 60 min to induce the levels and genome-wide binding of ADV-1::V5. Replicates are mapped as independent tracks to the genome of N. crassa OR74A.

link.text: View this Data Set in the Genome Browser

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Sachs_Light_Regulated_Genes_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Analysis of light-regulated genes Neurospora crassa OR74A
datasetPresenter.description: Comprehensive analysis of Neurospora crassaâs light-controlled gene regulatory networks were accessed by RNA-seq analysis. cDNA libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSequation 2000 for 57 cycles and processed with Illumina pipeline RTA 1.13.48 and CASAVA v1.8.2. Data were obtained from dark-grown cells were compared to cells exposed to light for 15, 60, 120, and 240 min. Both known and novel light-induced genes were identified including those whose transcript levels decreased in response to light.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_massSpec_non-limiting_conditions_phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium graminearum phosphoproteome in non-limiting conditions.
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium graminearum is perhaps the most serious pathogen of wheat worldwide, causing losses to Fusarium Head Blight every year in all temperate climates. Infected grain is of poor quality and is contaminated with tricothecene andestrogenic mycotoxins. F. graminearum is a multi-cellular fungus that can be grown in vitro and whose complete sequence has been published, two attributes that greatly facilitate proteomics-based analyses. This study presents a high-throughput proteomic analysis of phosphopeptides from F. graminearum strain DAOM 233423 grown in vitro without nutritional limitation. Using a combination of strong cation exchange (SCX) and immobilized metal affinity chromatography(IMAC) followed by LC-MS. A total of 2902 putative phosphopeptides were identified and then queried against the genome of F. graminearum PH-1 (NRRL31084).

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_Freitag_histonemod_nitrogenLevel_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: ChiP-Seq analysis of histone modifications in F. graminearum PH-1 strains grown on media with high or low nitrogen levels.
datasetPresenter.description: WT and kmt6 mutant of Fusarium graminearum were grown in high and low nitrogen conditions. ChIP was carried out on mycelia grown by inoculating conidia into 100ml of DVK medium for 3 days. ChIP-Seq was performed with anibodies against histone modifications known to be associated with active (H3K4me2) or silent (H3K9me3 and H3K27me3) chromatin, as well as H3K36me3. ChIP libraries for WT and kmt6 mutant strains gwown on high and low nitrogen and kmt6+ complemented strain grown on high nitrogen were sequenced on Illumina GAII or Illumina HiSeq2000.

link.text: View this Data Set in the Genome Browser

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_koAndWt_variousCarbonSources_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Identification of direct target genes of the Neurospora crassa essential plant biomass deconstruction transcription factors CLR-1, CLR-2 and XLR-1 (ChIP-Seq)
datasetPresenter.summary: ChIPseq upon knockout mutants and sild type growing on various carbon sources to determin the role of the transcription factors: CLR-1, CLR-2, and XLR-1 in plant cell wall degradation
datasetPresenter.description:
The plant cell wall is composed of many complex polymers, and its deconstruction requires an equally complex orchestration of a wide array of enzymes. In Neurospora crassa, clr-1, clr-2 and xlr-1 have been identified as the key transcription factors involved in cell wall breakdown. In order to define their regulons, we performed ChIPseq upon these three transcription factors.

Flasks containing sucrose were inoculated with conidia and incubated 16Â h at 25°C under conditions of constant light at 220Â  rpm. The culture was filtered, rinsed, and transferred to 100Â ml fresh VMM containing 1&percent; cellulose, hemicellulose, or sucrose as the sole carbon source for 4Â h. In addition, N.Â crassa clr-1-gfp, mc-clr-2, pccg-1-gfp, and pccg-1-mCherry strains were grown for 16Â h on sucrose and switched to Avicel for 24Â h prior to fixation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation was carried out using versions of previously published protocols.

datasetPresenter.displayName: Analysis of the protein kinase A-regulated proteome of Cryptococcus neoformans
datasetPresenter.description: The opportunistic fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans causes life-threatening meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. The expression of virulence factors including capsule and melanin is in part regulated by the cyclic-AMP/Protein Kinase A (PKA) signal transduction pathway. This study investigates the influence of PKA on the composition of the intracellular proteome to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the regulation that underpins virulence. PGAL7::PKA1 strains were grown under Pka1-repression (glucose-containing medium) and Pka1-induction (galactose-containing medium) conditions.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_microarrayExpression_transcriptome_during_the_infection_of_wheat_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of Fusarium graminearum during the infection of wheat
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of Fusarium graminearum during the infection of wheat
datasetPresenter.description: Wheat (Triticum aestivum) cultivar Bobwhite spikelets were point inoculated at anthesis with 10 Âµl of conidial suspension of PH-1 (105 spores/ml) or water control (mock) in 0.01 % Triton 60 solution. After inoculation, the plants were placed in a growth chamber at 16Â°C night (8h), 18Â°C day (16h). To ensure proper disease severity the spikes were covered with plastic bags for 48h to increase the humidity. Three biological replicates were conducted at 24, 48, 72, 96, 144 and 192h after inoculation (hai). Water treated (mock) spikes from the 0h time point was used as a control. For each biological replication, four spikes were randomly sampled, and immediately frozen at -80Â°C prior to RNA extraction. At each of the time points, spikes were sampled around 3 p.m.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_microarrayExpression_wheat_symptomless_symptomatic_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fusarium graminearum transcriptome during symptomless and symptomatic wheat infection
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Fgraminearum symptomless and symptomatic wheat infection Marray
datasetPresenter.summary: Fusarium head blight of wheat is one of the most serious and hazardous crop diseases worldwide. A genomeâwide transcriptomic investigation is used to examine the early phases of the F. graminearum â wheat head interaction, exploring both symptomless and symptomatic infections of wheat.
datasetPresenter.description: The analysis of the Fusarium graminearum transcriptome during symptomless and symptomatic infections of wheat floral tissue at 7 days post infection, to identify the correct spatio-temperol regulation of multiple virulence strategies. Methods: The RNAs from pairs of rachis internodes with the same macroscopic symptoms were combined from 15 wheat heads, including symptomless infection (RI5 + RI6), intermediate disease symptoms (RI3 + RI4) and fully symptomatic infection (RI1 + RI2). The RNA from the inoculated spikelet (SP1) was not combined. Three independent biological replicates for each tissue per treatment at 7 dpi were analysed. Purified total RNA (>10 Âµg) was in vitro transcribed, labelled using the BioArray high-yield RNA transcript labelling kit (T7), according to the manufacturer's instructions (Enzo Life Science, UK).
