datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_phenotype_GeneImage_NAFeaturePhenotypeImage_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Neurospora Genome Project Phenotype Image Collection
datasetPresenter.summary: Systematic characterisation of colony growth and morphology of Neurospora crassa knock out mutants.
datasetPresenter.description:
Analysis of colony growth and morphology was performed on solid Vogelâs minimal (MIN) medium. Petri dishes inoculated at their centres and then incubated at both 25Â°C and 37Â°C for 24h. For each strain, the hyphae at the edge of the colony and plate growth were photographed. Plate images were taken at 24h to document growth and morphology.

The Neurospora Genome Project was funded by NIGMS for two successive 5 year periods, the longest period allowed by NIGMS for Program Project Grants. Because funding has expired reagents, strains and tools have been archived and are available elsewhere as described below, but descriptions of some resources are available here.

Through the efforts of the project a number of resources have been provided to the fungal genetics community including molecularly validated knockouts for all the genes in Neurospora crassa, and a large number of knockouts of Aspergillus nidulans (including a full collection of kinase knockouts) as well as primers for creating knockouts for the entire Aspergillus nidulans genome, printed microarrays, a dense SNP map for Neurospora, and a variety of other tools. These reagents and strains have all been deposited into the Fungal Genetics Stock Center where they are available for a nominal fee.

There are searchable spreadsheets available on the FGSC website that will direct users to the appropriate strain numbers.

Neurospora knockout strains are available at Fungal Genetics Stock Center (FGSC).

Because there are so many strains, these are available both individually and as arrayed sets in 96 well plates.

It should be noted that while the knockouts were being created there was ongoing annotation of the genome with the result that individual gene annotations frequently changed. As a result, while most knockouts are correct, there will be cases where a single gene is represented by two separate knockouts (if the annotation at the time the cassettes were created represented exons as separate genes) and cases where not all exons have been removed. The primers used for each knockout are available on this web site (below) and can be mapped to the genome to identify exactly the region replaced with the knockout cassette.

Most of the knockouts were molecularly validated by Southern Blotting to be certain that the targeted gene was indeed the one and only site of insertion of genetic material. However, it is well understood that transformation is mutagenic process so users should be aware of the possibility that secondary mutations could have occurred so best practice will be to send the knockout through a cross, selecting for the hygromycin resistance that marks the knockout, and then screening to be sure that phenotype(s) associated with the knockout co-segregate with the hygromycin resistance.

Multiple attempts were made to knock out every gene so if the gene knockout you seek is unavailable as a homokaryon the gene is probably essential. In most cases such knockouts are available as heterokaryons. There were however a handful of cases where knockouts were not achieved despite repeated attempts for reasons that were never clear.

As a convenience we have maintained availability here of spreadsheets describing the primers used for knockout cassette construction as well as protocols for making knockouts.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_phenotype_knockout_mutants_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Phenotypic analysis of Neurospora crassa knockout mutants
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Phenotypic analysis of Neurospora crassa knockout mutants
datasetPresenter.summary: Phenotypic analysis of Neurospora crassa knockout mutants. A phenotypic pipeline was designed for high-throughput analysis of 10 different traits during hyphal growth, asexual sporulation (macroconidiation) and the sexual cycle in knockout mutants from Neurospora crassa.
datasetPresenter.description:
Overview. Near-isogenic wild type strains FGSC4200 (mata) and/or FGSC2489 (matA) were used as a control for all determinations. The methods described in [1] were used as the basis for the phenotypic methods.

Basal Hyphae Growth Rate (Quantitative Trait) Glass or disposable race tubes containing 13ml VM agar medium [2-4] were used for measurements. At least 4 replicate tubes were needed for each strain. One end of the race tube was inoculated with conidia or hyphae from a strain and the cap or plug replaced. Tubes were then incubated overnight at 25Â°C at ambient conditions [5] or in the dark [6-9]. The growth front of the strain was then marked on the tube using a marker (t=0). The growth front was subsequently marked at least twice/day over the next 3-4 days (noting time for each mark) or until the growth front reached the other end of the tube. The total growth in mm was then measured for each time point and a plot of mm vs. time used to determine growth rate. A minimum of four replicates with R2 > 0.95 were used to obtain the average growth rate for each strain.

The wild type growth rate range for data obtained from [5] and the Broad Institute Neurospora Database was 70-85 mm/day. The range for [6] was 65-80 mm/day and [7] was 73 mm/day. The range for [8] was 77-80 mm/day and [9] was 75-85 mm/day. For quantitative growth and developmental assays (apical extension rate and aerial hyphae height), mutants that exhibited a 5mm/day difference relative to wild type were considered significant [5,6]. Binned data from [8] and/or the Broad Institute Database were averaged to allow comparison to actual growth rate measurements in [9].

Aerial Hyphae Height (Quantitative Trait) Aerial hyphal extension was measured in VM standing liquid cultures. Test tubes containing 2-3 ml of liquid medium were inoculated at the liquid surface and incubated statically (typically in the dark) at 25Â°C 3-4 days. Total height (in mm) was recorded, measuring between the top of the floating cell pad and the top of the aerial hyphae. A minimum of 4 replicates was analyzed for each strain.

The wild type aerial hyphae height range for [5,9] was 30-45mm. The range for [6] was 15-45mm, for [8] was 38.2-46.7mm and for [7] was 46mm.

Macroconidia (Conidia) Production in Slants (Qualitative Trait) Slant tubes (13x100mm) containing 3 ml VM agar medium were inoculated with strains and grown at room temperature for 6 to 8 days under ambient light conditions [5, Broad Institute Neurospora Database] or for 3 days in the dark at 30Â°C and 4 days in the light at room temperature [6-9]. Production of conidia was scored visually. A minimum of 4 replicates was analyzed for each strain.

Female Fertility (Qualitative Traits) For analysis of female sexual fertility, strains were inoculated on 18x150mm slants containing 6 ml Synthetic Crossing Medium agar (SCM) and incubated under ambient light/dark or constant light conditions at room temperature.

Protoperithecia: After 7-8 days of incubation, cultures were scored for the number, size and pigmentation of protoperithecia by inspection using a stereomicroscope (Leica S8APO or Olympus SZX9).

Perithecia: The 7-8 day old SCM cultures were fertilized using a suspension of wild-type conidia of the opposite mating type (in water), applied using disposable sterile swabs. Cultures were returned to the same conditions used for protoperithecial development. After 7 days of incubation (~2 weeks total), cultures were scored for the number, size, pigmentation and/or submerged status of perithecia using a stereomicroscope.

Ascospores: The 2 week old SCM cultures were returned to the same culture conditions used for perithecial development. After 7 more days of incubation (~3 weeks total), cultures were scored for the number, size and pigmentation of ascospores shot onto the glass using a stereomicroscope. Perithecial beak morphology was also scored at this point.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Townsend_Transcriptome_SexualDevelopment_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Multidimensional regulation in transcriptome during sexual development in Neurospora crassa
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide analysis of N. crassa gene expression during sexual development. Transcriptomic sequencing was primed by random and multitargeted primers and accessed across eight time points encompassing the morphological changes and tissue and cellular development of maturing perithecia.
datasetPresenter.description:
Fungi exhibit a huge diversity in morphology and ecology, and genetic basis of morphological development in sexual reproduction of multi-cellular fungi has not been fully investigated with genome-wide approaches. Model organism Neurospora crassa is the very first sequenced genome for multi-cellular fungi, and well-annotated genome and gene markers characterized for key morphological traits make N. crassa an ideal platform to investigate transcriptome and its regulation during sexual development. RNA sequencing with different priming strategies have been efficient to provide fine-scale transcriptome landscapes for a multiple-staged development process. RNA were sampled for eight time points cross perithecial development, including two points right before and after crossing, for which mat A protoperithecia were fertilized with mat a conidia.
Methods. Two strains of N. crassa of complementary mating types, FGSC4200 and FGSC2489, were grown on carrot agar medium (CA). Perithecia at similar development stages (based on size and color under the stereomicroscope) were collected at 24, 48, 72, 96, 120, and 144 h after crossing. A multitargeted primer (MTP; VWNVNNBDKGGC) primed reverse transcription of the first cDNA strand, and random hexamers (N6; Invitrogen) primed the second cDNA strand. To provide technical replicates across stages of sexual development, cDNA was prepared using only N6 primers for samples at all time points. Single-end 35-bp reads of MTP- and N6-primed preparations were separately sequenced, each on eight lanes of an Illumina genome analyzer, at the Yale Center for Genomic Analysis.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_smallNcRna_Stajich_Small_RNA_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Small RNA sequence profiles during sexual development in Neurospora crassa
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Small RNAs profiles during sexual development stages of Neurospora crassa
datasetPresenter.summary: Endogenous small RNA profiles from N. crassa protoperithecia and perithecia at 2 and 4 days postfertilization.
datasetPresenter.description: Protoperithecia (PP) was collected under a dissecting microscope after 10 d of growth, at room temperature in light/dark conditions. Additional plates of PP were crossed with either the wild-type FGSC 8820 or delta sad-1 strains. Regions enriched with perithecia were collected after 2 and 4 d postfertilization (PF). Total RNAs from PP, 2d PF, 4d PF were extracted with an miRNeasy Mini kit (QIAGEN). Small RNA sequencing libraries were constructed using Illumina TruSeq Small RNA Sample Prep kit in the University of Utah Sequencing Core.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_Xu_Stage_Specific_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Stage-specific and genome-wide gene expression during the different developmental stages of Fusarium graminearum
datasetPresenter.summary: Stand specific RNA-Seq of F. graminerum growth stages (conidia, vegetative hyphae, and perithecia at 6dpi)
datasetPresenter.description: For RNA-seq analysis F. graminerum PH-1 conidia were collected from 5-day-old CMC cultures, vegetative hyphae were harvested from 24 h liquid YEPD cultures, and perithecia were collected from mating cultures 8 days post-fertilization (dpf). RNA was isolated and purified with the RNAprep Pure Plant Kit (Tiangen Biotech, Beijing, China). RNA was isolated from two independent biological replicates. Strand- specific RNA-seq libraries were prepared with the NEBNext UltraTM Directional RNA Library Prep Kit (NEB, USA) and sequenced with Illumina HiSeq 2500 at the 2x150 bp paired-end read mode.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_HD_Genotypes_Comparison_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative transcriptomics of C. neoformans mutants defective in heterochromatin regulation
datasetPresenter.summary: Stranded RNA-Seq profiles of WT, knockout strains of ezh2, msl1, ccc1, clr4, and ccc1-W52A aromatic cage mutant
datasetPresenter.description:
In this study authors identified and characterised a PRC2 complex in a budding yeast, Cryptococcus neoformans, and described the effect of H3K27me3 domains on gene expression in C. neoformans. Transcriptomic data were collected from WT, knockout strains of ezh2, msl1, ccc1, clr4, and ccc1-W52A aromatic cage mutant.

Total RNA was isolated using TRIzol (Invitrogen), mRNA was isolated using the Oligotex mRNA mini kit (QIAGEN). Two biological replicate sequencing libraries were prepared for each genotype using the NEBNext Ultra Directional RNA Library Prep Kit (New England Biolabs).

Ezh2 is the H3K27 methyltransferase and Eed1 is an ortholog of EED/Esc, a WD40 repeat containing protein that binds EZH2/E(z) and stimulates EZH2/E(z) activity. Msl1 is a fungal ortholog of RbAp46/48/Nurf55, a WD repeat protein that associates with PRC2 but is not required for EZH2/E(z) activity and has additional roles in other chromatin-modifying complexes. Bnd1, a big protein with no domains and Ccc1, a protein that contains a chromodomain and a coiled coil region are components of C. neoformans PRC2 machinery with no clear orthologs in higher eukaryotes.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_Wang_VegetativeAndInfectiousGrowth_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomic analysis during vegetative and infectious growth of Fusarium graminearum PH-1
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptomes during vegetative and infectious growth
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA-Seq of F. graminearum mycelia and 6dpi infection samples assessed by paired-end deep Illumina sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description: Freshly harvested F. graminearum PH-1 conidia from carboxymethyl cellulose cultures were re-suspended in sterile distilled water. Flowering wheat heads of cultivar XiaoYan 22 were drop-inoculated with 10 ul of conidium suspensions as described previously (PMID: 25040476). Total RNAs were extracted with TRIzol (Invitrogen, USA) and treated with RNase-free DNase I. RNA-seq libraries with the average insert size of 300 bp were constructed as described in the manufacture. Illumina deep sequencing with paired-end 2 x 125 bp model were performed at Novogene Bioinformatics Technology (Beijing, China).

datasetPresenter.name: foxyrace1_Guo_banana_pathogen_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomics of banana pathogen Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. cubense race 1
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptome of Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. Cubense
datasetPresenter.summary: Strand specific RNA-Seq analysis of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense infecting Musa acuminata 0h and 48h.
datasetPresenter.description: The asexual fungus Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc) causing vascular wilt disease is one of the most devastating pathogens of banana (Musa spp.). Stranded RNA-Seq samples were prepared by incubating Foc isolate N2 (Foc1) in a 250 ml-flask with 150 ml of PDB (potato dextrose broth) and then harvesting the mycelia and spores. For inoculation treatment, the Foc1 culture was suspended in sterile water and then inoculated to the roots of 'Brazil'banana plantlets for 48 h in the hydroponics system. RNA isolation and reverse transcription for cDNA synthesis were carried out using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, USA) and the PrimeScript RT reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (Takara, Japan) according the manufactoryâs direction.

datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomics of banana pathogen F. oxysporum f.sp. cubense race 4
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptome of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. Cubense 4
datasetPresenter.summary: Strand specific RNA-Seq analysis of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense_4 infecting Musa acuminata at 0h and 48h.
datasetPresenter.description: The asexual fungus Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense (Foc) causing vascular wilt disease is one of the most devastating pathogens of banana (Musa spp.). Stranded RNA-Seq samples were prepared by incubating Foc isolate N2 (Foc1) in a 250 ml-flask with 150 ml of PDB (potato dextrose broth) and then harvesting the mycelia and spores. For inoculation treatment, the Foc1 culture was suspended in sterile water and then inoculated to the roots of 'Brazil'banana plantlets for 48 h in the hydroponics system. RNA isolation and reverse transcription for cDNA synthesis were carried out using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, USA) and the PrimeScript RT reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (Takara, Japan) according the manufactoryÂs direction. Deep sequencing. Libraries were processed using Illumina HiSeq 2000 technology.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Liu_VegetativeAndSexualDevelopment_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: N. crassa transcriptomes during vegetative and sexual development stage
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptomes during vegetative and sexual development stage
datasetPresenter.summary: Strand-specific RNA-Seq of Neurospora crassa growth stages
datasetPresenter.description: N.crassa WT, sad-1, and stc-1 strains were used in this study. Samples were collected from hyphae (control) and 3, 4, and 5 days post fertilization (dpf). RNA was extracted and purified with the RNAprep Pure Plant Kit (Tiangen Biotech). Poly(A) mRNA was then isolated with the NEBNext Poly(A) mRNA Magnetic Isolation Module (New England Biolabs). Strand-specific RNA-seq libraries were prepared with the NEBNext Ultra Directional RNA Library Prep Kit (New England Biolabs) following the instructions provided by the manufacturer and sequenced with an Illumina HiSeq 2500 system using the 2 x 150-bp paired-end read mode. For each sample, two independent biological replicates were used for RNA-seq. .

datasetPresenter.name: cimmRS_Kirkland_TE_GFF_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coccidioides immitis RS TE GBrowse track
datasetPresenter.summary: Annotation of transposable elements (TE) in Coccidioides immitis RS using RepeatMasker which identified TEs based on the RepBase reference library and REPET to support de novo TE identification.
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis and Coccidioides posadasii are primary pathogenic fungi that cause disease in immunologically-competent animals and people. The organism is found exclusively in arid regions of the Southwestern United States, Mexico, and South America, but not in other parts of the world. The expression of protein coding genes is often influenced by TEs. This dataset presents a detailed analysis of the transposable elements (TE) in C. immitis RS. TE annotation was performed using RepeatMasker which identified TEs based on the RepBase reference library and REPET to support de novo TE identification.

datasetPresenter.name: cimmRS_microarrayExpression_Viriyakosol_Mycelia_Differentiation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Gene expression changes during mycelia differentiation in Coccidioides immitis
datasetPresenter.summary: A custom open reading frame oligonucleotide microarray to compare the transcriptome of C. immitis mycelia with two spherule samples grown in vitro.
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes disease in mammals, including human beings. It grows as a mycelium containing arthroconidia in the soil and in the host arthroconidia differentiates into a unique structure called a spherule. We used a custom open reading frame oligonucleotide microarray to compare the transcriptome of C. immitis mycelia with early (day 2) and late stage (day 8) spherules grown in vitro. All hybridizations were done in quadruplicate and stringent criteria were used to identify significantly differentially expressed genes.

datasetPresenter.name: cposC735deltSOWgp_Kirkland_TE_GFF_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coccidioides posadasii C735 TE GBrowse track
datasetPresenter.summary: Annotation of transposable elements (TE) in Coccidioides posadasii C735 using RepeatMasker which identified TEs based on the RepBase reference library and REPET to support de novo TE identification
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis and Coccidioides posadasii are primary pathogenic fungi that cause disease in immunologically-competent animals and people. The organism is found exclusively in arid regions of the Southwestern United States, Mexico, and South America, but not in other parts of the world. The expression of protein coding genes is often influenced by TEs. This dataset presents a detailed analysis of the transposable elements (TE) in C. posadasii C735. TE annotation was performed using RepeatMasker which identified TEs based on the RepBase reference library and REPET to support de novo TE identification.

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_phenotype_Fusarium_Pheno_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Manually curated phenotypes for Fusarium species.
datasetPresenter.description: The phenotypes for Fusarium graminearum PH-1 in FungiDB represent the phenotype data that is manually curated from the publications "A phenome-based functional analysis of transcription factors in the cereal head blight fungus, Fusarium graminearum" (PMID:22028654) and "Functional analysis of the Fusarium graminearum phosphatome" (PMID:25758923). The phenotypes from these publications were organised with ontologies to enable the search of this dataset with user-defined queries. We have followed a post-compositional ("entity + quality") approach for phenotype annotation and mapped the phenotypes to multiple ontologies. The primary ontology for "quality" terms is Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO). Gene Ontology (GO), Fungal Gross Anatomy Ontology (FAO), Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) and Ascomycete Phenotype Ontology (APO) were used for "entity" terms. GO was preferred over other ontologies and was used to annotate phenotypic observations relating to biological processes and molecular functions. Similarly, FAO and ChEBI were used to annotate phenotypes relating to fungal structures and chemical compounds respectively. APO terms were still used for curation, if these phenotypic terms were missing in other ontologies and they are beyond the scope of other ontologies used (e.g. colony morphology). We plan to expand this dataset in future releases by incorporating phenotype annotations from additional publications.

datasetPresenter.name: hcapH143_Gilmore_YeastAndHyphal_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative transcriptomes of yeast hyphal forms in Histoplasma capsulatum H143
datasetPresenter.summary: Analysis of yeast and hyphal transcript expression patterns in Histoplasma capsulatum H143 grown at 37°C and room temperature (RT), respectively.
datasetPresenter.description: To compare yeast and hyphal transcript expression patterns cultures were grown at 37C for yeast-phase growth and at room temperature (RT) for hyphal phase growth. Total RNA was then isolated from biological duplicates of yeast or hyphal cultures and strand specific cDNA libraries were created from poly(A)-enriched RNA and sequenced using paired-end deep-sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: caurB8441_HTS_SNP_CDC_Whole_Genome_Sequencing_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genome sequence reads - Candida auris isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole-genome sequencing of Candida auris isolates using Illumina HiSeq 2500.
datasetPresenter.description: Samples were collected from patients, patient contacts, healthcare workers, and the environment in 4 hospitals with recent C. auris outbreaks. Using standardized protocols, people were swabbed at different body sites. Patient and procedure rooms were sectioned into 4 zones and surfaces were swabbed. We performed whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and antifungal susceptibility testing (AFST) on all isolates. DNA was extracted using the ZR Fungal/Bacterial DNA MiniPrep kit (Zymo Research, Irvine, California). Genomic libraries were constructed using the NEBNext Ultra DNA Library Prep kit for Illumina (New England Biolabs, Ipswich, Massachusetts) and sequenced on Illumina HiSeq 2500 (Illumina, San Diego, California) using the HiSeq Rapid SBS Kit v2 500-cycle (Illumina). Samples were only used that had at least 50Ã coverage.

datasetPresenter.name: caurB8441_HTS_SNP_Lockhart_Multidrug_Resistant_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genome sequence reads - Candida auris isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Multidrug-resistant Candida auris isolates were collected from on 3 continents and sequenced Illumina HiSeq 2500 technology.
datasetPresenter.description: Candida auris, a multidrug-resistant yeast that causes invasive infections, was first described in 2009 in Japan and has since been reported from several countries. To understand the global emergence and epidemiology of C. auris, isolates from patients with C. auris infections in Pakistan, India, South Africa, and Venezuela during 2012-2015 and the type specimen from Japan were sequenced.

datasetPresenter.name: plutPb01_HTS_SNP_Munoz_WGS_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome sequencing of P. lutzii isolates.
datasetPresenter.description: The Paracoccidioides genus includes two species of thermally dimorphic fungi that cause paracoccidioidomycosis, a neglected health-threatening human systemic mycosis endemic to Latin America. To examine the genome evolution and the diversity of Paracoccidioides spp., whole-genome sequencing was performed on isolates of P. lutzii by constructing paired end libraries sequenced on Illumina HiSeq 2000.

datasetPresenter.name: anigCBS513-88_array_microarrayCoexpressionMeyer_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Co-expression network of over 4.5 million robust correlation relationships was generated from 283 microarray experiments.
datasetPresenter.description: A meta-analysis of 155 transcriptomics experiments generated genome level co-expression networks for 9579 genes of Aspergillus niger genome. A manuscript titled "Updating genome annotation for the microbial cell factory Aspergillus niger using gene co-expression networks" is available at bioRxiv.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_quantitativeMassSpec_Geddes_Secretome_Profiling_quant_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Secretome profiling of Pka-1 regulated proteins in Cryptococcus neoformans (16, 48, 72, and 120 hr post inoculation)
datasetPresenter.summary: Targeted secretome profiling of Pka-1 regulated proteins in C. neoformans was performed at 16, 48, 72, and 120 hr post-inoculation in Pka-1 inductive and repressive media.
datasetPresenter.description: The pathogenic yeast Cryptococcus neoformans causes life-threatening meningoencephalitis in individuals suffering from HIV/AIDS. The cyclic-AMP/protein kinase A (PKA) signal transduction pathway regulates the production of extracellular virulence factors in C. neoformans, but the influence of the pathway on the secretome has not been investigated. In this study, quantitative proteomics was performed using galactose-inducible (PGAL4::PKA1+G) and glucose-repressible (PGAL4::PKA1+D) expression of the PKA1 gene encoding the catalytic subunit of PKA in order to identify regulated proteins in the secretome. Supernatant cultures were collected at 16, 48, 72, 120 hr post-inoculation protein extraction was done using standard protocol.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_Glass_CellWallDegradation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomic investigation of N. crassa CLR-1, CLR-2, and XLR-1 roles in plant cell wall degradation
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Ncra role of the transcription factors in plant cell wall degradations
datasetPresenter.summary: Differential gene expression analysis performed in N. crassa strains grown on xylan, sucrose, and no carbon.
datasetPresenter.description: RNA-Seq analysis was performed in N. crassa WT (FGSC 2489), Δxlr-1 (6971), and xlr-1-A828V strains. Both WT and Δxlr-1 were grown for 16h in VMM and switched to xylan for 4h (_4X_Vogels). xlr-1-A828V strain was also grown for 16h in VMM and switched for 4h to sucrose (_4S_Vogels) or no carbon media (_4N_Vogels).

datasetPresenter.name: cneoH99_HTS_SNP_Cuomo_387_Isolates_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genome sequence reads - Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome sequencing data from 387 C. neoformans var. grubii isolates
datasetPresenter.description: Isolates from various lineages we sequenced (185 from global VNI lineage, 186 from African VNB, and 16 from VNII lineage corresponding to non-recombining split in VNB (VNBI and VNBII). Genomic DNA was sheared to ~250 bp using a Covaris LE instrument and libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq to generate 101 base reads. Reads were aligned to the C. neoformans var. grubii H99 assembly.

datasetPresenter.name: ncraOR74A_HTS_SNP_Glass_FilamentousFungus_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genome sequence reads - Neurospora crassa wild type isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide association study (GWAS) to identify novel loci underlying trait variation in the wild isolates of the filamentous fungus Neurospora crassa.
datasetPresenter.description: Whole-genome sequence was generated from a subset of 25 N. crassa strains from a collection of 112 strains of a single Louisiana population.

datasetPresenter.name: pbraPb03_HTS_SNP_Cuomo_Raw_Sequence_Reads_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome sequencing of P. brasiliensis isolates
datasetPresenter.description:
The Paracoccidioides genus includes two species of thermally dimorphic fungi that cause paracoccidioidomycosis, a neglected health-threatening human systemic mycosis endemic to Latin America. To examine the genome evolution and the diversity of Paracoccidioides spp., whole-genome sequencing was performed on 27 isolates of P. brasiliensis.

In FungiDB, this dataset was aligned to P. brasiliensis Pb03 while authors used P. brasiliensis Pb18 as a reference genome. This dataset will be re-mapped to P. brasiliensis Pb18 in Release 44.

datasetPresenter.name: anigCBS513-88_Archer_LignocelluloseResponses_Willow_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomic response of Aspergillus niger to lignocellulose (willow)
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomic profiling of A. niger growing on lignocellulosic biofuel substrates (AB SOLiD System 3.0)
datasetPresenter.description: Transcriptomic profiling of Aspergillus niger when exposed to wheat straw as a model lignocellulosic substrate. Triplicate samples of A. niger N402 taken at each of three timepoints: (1) After 48h growth in minimal media with Glucose as sole carbon source (Glucose), (2) after transfer to willow media for 24h (Willow), and (3) 5h after after the exogenous addition of glucose to the willow straw media (Willow + Glucose).

templateInjector.prop: Triplicate samples of A. niger N402 taken at each of three timepoints: After 48 h growth in minimal media with Glucose as sole carbon source (Glucose 48h), after transfer to willow media for 24 h (Willow 24h), and 5 h after after the exogenous addition of glucose to the willow straw media (Willow+Glucose)

datasetPresenter.name: calbSC5314_HTS_SNP_Lindquist_AmBResistant_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genome sequence reads - Candida albicans evolution of resistance to amphotericin B
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome sequencing of wild-type, clinical isolates, and laboratory-evolved strains of Candida albicans
datasetPresenter.description: Candida albicans, the leading fungal pathogen of humans, rapidly evolves resistance to two major antifungal classes, the triazoles and echinocandins. In contrast, resistance to the third major antifungal used in the clinic, amphotericin B (AmB), remains extremely rare despite 50 years of use as monotherapy. A whole genome sequencing of rare AmB-resistant clinical isolates as well as laboratory-evolved strains was performed to identify and investigate mutations that confer AmB resistance in vitro.

datasetPresenter.name: cgatWM276_microarrayExpression_May_23isolates_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparison of gene expression in Cryptococcus gattii clinical isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Trascriptomics study of C.gattii clinical isolates recovered during Vancouver Island outbreak in Canada.
datasetPresenter.description: An array analysis of C. gattii (C. bacillosporus), intended to identify loci associated with the hypervirulence of the Vancouver Island Outbreak (VIO). 23 C. gattii isolates, representing both VIO strains and control strains, were grown for 24 hours in mammalian macrophages. RNA was isolated and gene expression for each strain quantified relative to pooled RNA from all 23 samples.

templateInjector.prop: RMA Normalized Values (log base 2 generated with RMAExpress v1.0.3)

datasetPresenter.name: fgraPH-1_Son_HeatStressed_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of heat-stressed Fusarium graminearum Z-3639
datasetPresenter.summary: Illumina HiSeq 2000 of 24 h-old mycelia from complete medium incubated in 25C and 37C for 15 min.
datasetPresenter.description: The ascomycete fungus Fusarium graminearum causes devastating Fusarium head blight in major cereal crops worldwide, leading to not only yield and quality losses but also contamination with harmful mycotoxins. F. graminearum produces sexual spores (ascospores) within perithecia and asexual spores (conidia) on or within plant residues, including small grain stems and roots as well as maize stalks and ear pieces. These spores are resistant to environmental stress conditions and are well suited for dispersal; genome-wide transcriptome analysis of cellular adaptation to thermal stress was performed on the plant pathogenic fungus Fusarium graminearum. For the RNA-Seq analysis of Fusarium graminearum wild-type strain Z-3639 2 samples (3 replicates each) were collected: 24 h-old mycelia from complete medium (CM) incubated in normal temperature (25C) and in high temperature (37C) for 15 min.

datasetPresenter.name: caurB8441_Ramage_ClinicalIsolates_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome profiling of Candida auris clinical isolates forming biofilm
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptome of C. auris clinical isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomic investigation of isolates collected by Public Health England, UK using Illumina HiSeq X Ten technology.
datasetPresenter.description: Candida auris has emerged as a significant global nosocomial pathogen. This is primarily due to its antifungal resistance profile but also its capacity to form adherent biofilm communities on a range of clinically important substrates. RNA-Seq analysis (with 3 biological replicates) was employed in studying the transcriptomic changes occuring during developing C. auris biofilms (clinical isolates NCPF8973 and NCPF8978). C. auris NCPF8973, originally isolated from a wound swab, was chosen for subsequent transcriptomic analysis. Biofilms were grown in 75-cm3 tissue culture flasks before being washed with PBS and dislodged using a cell scraper.

datasetPresenter.name: afumAf293_Irmer_Blood_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome analysis of Aspergillus fumigatus grown in blood
datasetPresenter.summary: Gene expression profile at various stages of an in vitro model of aspergillosis.
datasetPresenter.description: Mycelium of the A. fumigatus strain was grown 16 h in minimal medium, harvested, and pooled before transfer to the experimental culture conditions (pre). Subsequently cells grown under two conditions: minimal medium (M) and human blood (B). Two biological replicates were collected per each sample.

datasetPresenter.name: afumAf293_Bowyer_itraconazole_resistance_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomes of itraconazole-resistant strains derived from A1160, HapB and 29.9.
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptomes of Aspergillus fumigatus A1160, HapB and 29.9 strains.
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA-Seq of Aspergillus fumigatus mutants resistant to itraconazole.
datasetPresenter.description: Two mutant strains of Aspergillus fumigatus derived from strain A1160, HapB and 29.9, display resistance to the antifungal drug itraconazole. To understand what underlying transcriptional processes contribute to this resistance, A1160, HapB and 29.9 were cultured either in the presence or absence of itraconazole. Aspergillus fumigatus strains A1163 (FGSC), A1160 delta HapB (AFUB_030360) and A1160 delta NADH-ubiquinone oxidoreductase 29.9 kDa subunit (AFUB_026380) were cultivated at 37C with shaking (200 rpm) for 18 hours in 50 ml RPMI (250ml glass Erlenmeyer flasks). Mycelia was harvested and used to inoculate fresh cultures (50 ml RPMI +/- itraconazole at 1mg/l in 250ml glass Erlenmeyer flasks). Cultures were incubated for 4 hours at 37C with shaking (200rpm). Paired-end RNA-sequencing (HiSeq 2000) was used to compare transcription profiles of each mutant strain with or without the drug, to A1160 with or without drug.

datasetPresenter.name: cneoJEC21_Tian_Stranded_WT_cqs1delta_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Stranded RNA-Seq of WT and cqs1delta strains during sexual development stage
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Stranded RNA-Seq of WT and cqs1delta
datasetPresenter.summary: Stranded RNA-Seq of C. neoformans WT (XL280Î±) and cqs1delta strains grown on V8 media.
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptococcus neoformans is a prevalent fungal pathogen that has two defined sexual cycles (bisexual and unisexual). To investigate pathway signalling and interactions, RNA-Seq samples were collected in duplicated from WT (XL280Î±) and cqs1Î strains grown on V8 media supplemented with synthetic Qsp1 (for cqs1Î mutant only).

datasetPresenter.name: cneoJEC21_Tian_Sexual_Reproduction_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans sexual reproduction is controlled by a quorum sensing peptide
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomic analysis of gene expression in Cryptococcus neoformans var neoformans targeting pheromone pathways and quorum sensing.
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptococcus neoformans is a prevalent fungal pathogen that has two defined sexual cycles (bisexual and unisexual). To investigate pathway signalling and interactions, RNA-Seq samples were collected from WT (XL280Î±), cqs1Î, opt1Î, and cqs2Î mutants. Cells were cultured under extremely mating-inhibitory condition (YPD liquid medium) were transferred onto the plates containing either glucose or alternative sugar galactose as the sole carbon source for stimulating mating response. Samples were collected at 1, 6, 12, 24 and 72hr points. To investigate genes controlled by CGS1 transcriptomic studies were performed with _cqs1Î_mutant grown in the presence of various concentrations of synthetic Qsp1, Qsp2, or Qsp3 (4, 16, and 512nM).
